Posts.Content: Hello all, hope everyone had a wonderful christmas and a happy New Year. As I mentioned, dad was to have his incisional hernia repaired Jan 2nd, and the doctor said it went well, he put a mesh in to reinforce the muscle and tissue wall. He said problems like incisional hernias are quite common following daVinci robot surgery, and he's seen a lot of these cases in his practice. Bleeding was minimal and no complications were noted during the surgery. He does have a sore throat amd hoarse voice, which I'm assuming to be due to the breathing tube put in his throat. He is extremely, extremely sore in his abdomen, especially at the incision site, where the doctor aaid there are some staples. Dad has a big bandage wrapped around his back and abdomen, and it goes halfway up his chest and back. Discharge papers say he can take the bandage off after 48 hours post op, which would put it roughly 2:30-3:00pm ct, so we won't see the op site until then. With his blood clots from the davinci prostatectomy noted, the Dr said for dad to walk 10-15 minutes at least 3 times a day. Dad has already done 2 walks today, so we may go for 4 if he's not hurting too bad. What does worry me a bit is his oxygen saturation, our oximiter shows he had a oxygen sat of 92-94% at last check. I would like it to be at least 95% since he usually ran 97-98% prior to this surgery. Could the large bandage be affecting that? He says its quite tight and makes breathing a little uncomfortable, though he states he is not having shortness of breath. I know if a person's oxygen saturation drops below 90, that requires supplemental oxygen to bring it up. He states he is not nearly as weak this time around compared to his prostate surgery. I am staying extra vigilant with his blood clot history and his low oxygen saturation, and I'm staying awake overnight so I can keep an eye on him. He has the typical no lifting objects over 10-15 lbs for 6 weeks order followong such a procedure, and is to report to the doctor if he develops a fever of 100.5 F or higher. Also, it says on his discharge sheet, and the doctor stated as well, that he may have some drainage from the site, which is normal according to him, but if it becomes excessive, he is to report to the doctor or ER immediately. He has been given 40 hydrocodne 7.5 mg to take every 6 hours as need for pain, 21 antibiotic pills (cephalexin 500 mg) to take 3 times per day, and odansetron 4mg to be taken 1 tablet every 6 hours as needed for nausea. That's probably about it for now, but after talking to the doctor and reading up on some articles on daVinci surgery, I consider myself anti-robotic surgery, as does my father. He said if he could go over it again, he'd have neber considered the robot and went for the open surgery instead, especially if he knew it was going to cause him this misery and near death. But my opinion on the robot is another discussion for another time. Best wishes to all who are facing prostate cancer, and recovering from it, and best wishes to those of you whom may be caregivers to a PCa patient.

Posts.Title: Dad's prostate surgery hernia repaired

Posts.Content: pT3a N0 Mx(I assume) indicates prostate cancer that has escaped the prostate pseudocapsule-- not a true capsule since this layer does not elsurrouns the entire gland. But it has not extended into nearby tissues and has not spread into any lymphnodes. Your pathology report suggests that you had surgery on a moderately aggressive prostate cancer, and that the surgery didn't quite get 100% of it, hence the positive margins. There is no need to do anything before your scheduled post op PSA test. Your results then will dictate what direction you need to go in. Gleason 4+3(7) cancer typically will indicate radiation following surgery anyway. You might not have to do it immediately afterward, but my guess is at some point it will be needed. Fortunately, they would utilize the radiation at that point still with curative intent. Family friend of ours had pT3a N0 Mx prostate cancer upon his surgery, with A Gleason score of 4+4=8, had a PSA just under 12. He had salvage radiation for it, and his PSA has been undetectable for over 8 years now. So while it is unfortunate there was positive margin involvement, and the primary pattern was 4, that by no means spells doom, not at all.

Posts.Title: My Pathology Staging Info, Could Use Some Thoughts On This

Posts.Content: I think having treatment now is prudent, gleason 7 and a psa over 10 really exclude you from being a candidate for active surveillance at such a young age. You have 3+4 according to your biopsy, and that is a SIGNIFICANT difference from the 4+3. 3+4 behaves more closely to gleason 6, though it does have the ability to spread thanks to the pattern 4 component. Still though its not terrible, and certainly is curable if confined to the prostste, or at least regionally contained. 4+3 would have been much more aggressive, being as its made more of pattern 4, and would spread quicker if it escaped the prostate, 4+3 behaves close to a gleason 8, which is quite agvressive. Surgical treatment is a good option because it will give you and your doctor abdefinituve picture, and you will know if it truly is organ confined, and know for certain the gleason grade. 20% of cases are upgraded to a higher gleason score be c ause the pathologist cannsee the whole prostate, and find higher grade disease the biopsy did not detect. Also, in the event of recurrence, youd have radiation as a 2nd shot to cure the disease. If you did radiation first and cancer returned, surgery wouldnt be likely recommended because radiation created scar tissue that is hard and leathery, and quite difficult to cut through. I think given your biopsy of 3+4, you should do fine, and chances of organ confined disease with no node involvement, or extraproztstic extension is good. Gleason 3+4 is in prognostic group 2 out of 5, which is still good. There feally is no.right or wrong treatment, you just do whwts best for you in terms of your clinical picture. And with a skilled physician, total nerve sparing can be achieved.

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice for surgery now.

Posts.Content: Fortunatwly the biopsy indicates low grade, gleason 6 prostate cancer. It is said that wssentially no man is at risk of death from gleason 6 prostate cancer because it lacks the mutations and de-differentiation to allow it to survive outside of the prostate, and therefore does not have the ability to metastasize. 4 cores being positive indicates a possibility of somebhigher grade cancer being present that warrants investigation. Maybe request your samples be sent off to a large facility for second opinion to be sure that it truly is gleason 6, and that there is no pattern 4 present, especially if that pattern 4 were to be the dominant pattern. If truly a gleason 6, you shpuld be fine in any case, and one treatment or another should do you well. Radiation therapy has about the same success rate as surgery in treating low and intermediate grade tumors. Highlander assured me, and many others who have G6 cancer, or have loved ones with it that no man dies from that disease, and all studies and research papers published in regards to gleason 6 verify that finding.

Posts.Title: So much for Active Surveillance, for me anyway

Posts.Content: Yup not at all surprised your PSA shot up with all that going on. That's a lot of stress on the urinary system, and can stimulate the prostate into producing excessive PSA. As stated above, PSA is not prostate cancer specific, that's just one of several possible causes of elevation in PSA. Inflammation, infection, recent sexual function are among the chief causes of that, as can riding a bike, or exercises that emphasize the lower abdomen-- it's as if it "squeezes the gland", which in turn secretes PSA. Very happy to hear your PSA came down after the regimen of cipro, that pretty much legs it as Infection or inflammation. Very wise idea to have your PSA tested like you did per your brother's history as well.

Surgical treatment is a good option because it will give you and your doctor abdefinituve picture, and you will know if it truly is organ confined, and know for certain the gleason grade. 20% of cases are upgraded to a higher gleason score be c ause the pathologist cannsee the whole prostate, and find higher grade disease the biopsy did not detect. Also, in the event of recurrence, youd have radiation as a 2nd shot to cure the disease. If you did radiation first and cancer returned, surgery wouldnt be likely recommended because radiation created scar tissue that is hard and leathery, and quite difficult to cut through. I think given your biopsy of 3+4, you should do fine, and chances of organ confined disease with no node involvement, or extraproztstic extension is good. Gleason 3+4 is in prognostic group 2 out of 5, which is still good. There feally is no.right or wrong treatment, you just do whwts best for you in terms of your clinical picture. And with a skilled physician, total nerve sparing can be achieved.

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice for surgery now.

Posts.Content: pT3a N0 Mx(I assume) indicates prostate cancer that has escaped the prostate pseudocapsule-- not a true capsule since this layer does not elsurrouns the entire gland. But it has not extended into nearby tissues and has not spread into any lymphnodes. Your pathology report suggests that you had surgery on a moderately aggressive prostate cancer, and that the surgery didn't quite get 100% of it, hence the positive margins. There is no need to do anything before your scheduled post op PSA test. Your results then will dictate what direction you need to go in. Gleason 4+3(7) cancer typically will indicate radiation following surgery anyway. You might not have to do it immediately afterward, but my guess is at some point it will be needed. Fortunately, they would utilize the radiation at that point still with curative intent. Family friend of ours had pT3a N0 Mx prostate cancer upon his surgery, with A Gleason score of 4+4=8, had a PSA just under 12. He had salvage radiation for it, and his PSA has been undetectable for over 8 years now. So while it is unfortunate there was positive margin involvement, and the primary pattern was 4, that by no means spells doom, not at all.

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice for surgery now.

Posts.Content: Fortunatwly the biopsy indicates low grade, gleason 6 prostate cancer. It is said that wssentially no man is at risk of death from gleason 6 prostate cancer because it lacks the mutations and de-differentiation to allow it to survive outside of the prostate, and therefore does not have the ability to metastasize. 4 cores being positive indicates a possibility of somebhigher grade cancer being present that warrants investigation. Maybe request your samples be sent off to a large facility for second opinion to be sure that it truly is gleason 6, and that there is no pattern 4 present, especially if that pattern 4 were to be the dominant pattern. If truly a gleason 6, you shpuld be fine in any case, and one treatment or another should do you well. Radiation therapy has about the same success rate as surgery in treating low and intermediate grade tumors. Highlander assured me, and many others who have G6 cancer, or have loved ones with it that no man dies from that disease, and all studies and research papers published in regards to gleason 6 verify that finding.

Posts.Title: My Pathology Staging Info, Could Use Some Thoughts On This

Posts.Content: Yup not at all surprised your PSA shot up with all that going on. That's a lot of stress on the urinary system, and can stimulate the prostate into producing excessive PSA. As stated above, PSA is not prostate cancer specific, that's just one of several possible causes of elevation in PSA. Inflammation, infection, recent sexual function are among the chief causes of that, as can riding a bike, or exercises that emphasize the lower abdomen-- it's as if it "squeezes the gland", which in turn secretes PSA. Very happy to hear your PSA came down after the regimen of cipro, that pretty much legs it as Infection or inflammation. Very wise idea to have your PSA tested like you did per your brother's history as well.

Posts.Title: PSA Dropped after 3 weeks of cipro

Posts.Content: Hello again, you may recall me posting in january that my dad's psa had risen to 0.13 and i had expressed concern over it. Well they did a re test today and the doctorbsaid "Mr Otinger, i Have good news, your PSA has fallen to <0.1, which is essentially ZERO. The ultrasensative assay we use can sometimes glitch and overestimate values, and that is what happened with your January test. You are good to go, and continue to enjoy being free of prostate cancer.  BIG sigh of relief there. So i can happily say he is still in "Club Zero"

Posts.Title: Dad's PSA re-test 5-30-17, great news

Posts.Content: Looks great to me, I mean, yeah nobody wants to be "upgraded" from 3+3 to 3+4, but that still isnt horrible. And your PSA is just fine. There can indeed be some residual PSA circulating in the bloodstream the first few weeks following a prostatectomy, then it should fall to an undetectable level after that. >.03 by every institution that I know of is considered undectable, and therefore, you are in the "Zero Club". All nodes, seminal vesicles, and margins being negative bodes well for the long term outlook.

Posts.Title: 6wks Post Ralp PSA result

Posts.Content: Yup, I agree with the others. With node involvement and cancer outside the gland, this is a wise plan.
Posts.Title: 3 Month Post RALP & Treatment Plan for Node Positive Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Good idea to get it investigated. You can get it done now or a couple weeks from now and be completely recovered from the biopsy, so it will not interfere with you going to your son's wedding. That jump in psa is more so concerning than the overall level. Prostate enlargement can elevate psa, but it can Olson hide prostate cancer. My dad had an enlarged prostate and his biopsy diagnosed gleason 6 with 5 of 12 cores positive. A gleason 6 shouldn't be a threat, but still, was glad to have done it in case there could have been some gleason 8 in there, which is quite aggressive and can become a major threat

At the same time, having a biopsy is a good idea, just for extra reassurance because the presence of PC could still be lurking and be masked by the BPH inspired PSA. Good luck! Posts.Title: Presence of perineural invasion, and its impact on outcome

Posts.Content: Hello once again everyone, one topic in prostate cancer I find of particular intrigue, and that is perineural invasion, both in biopsy and surgical pathology. Some articles have mentioned PNI as a negative factor in prognosis, especially if found on biopsy. Other articles have said it is of little significance. What is your take on this? Ill throw it out there that my dad had PNI in both the biopsyand surgical pathology. It was present in the left lobe, but not in the right.

Posts.Title: Incisional hernia developed after RALP

Posts.Content: Hello there, one much less likely possibility, but a very serious condition can manifest itself as swelling being a symptom, and fhat is deep vein thrombosis. Im not saying this to scare you or anything, but just to alert you to the small possibility. I saw my dad develop bilateral dvts as a result from his surgery, but his calves were also hard as rocks and he devellped a high fever as well. Warmness is also a concerning symptom in terms of dvt. Have you had cramps in your calves?

Posts.Title: Swelling in one leg

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, hope all of yall have a fantastic Independence Day, as we celebrate the birth of our great nation. If you plan on drinking and need to go somewhere, please be sure to have a DD. Let this be a great day for everyone. It has been a long time since I last posted, but as of my dad's most recent PSA test, his level was still << 0.04, as low as the machine his urologist uses will go, basically he said this is pretty much less than 0, and now being over a year post op, that is definitely a big milestone. Cancer recurrence chances seem to go down significantly with each year that passes, up to about 10 years or so. As far as holiday plans, I can't do much, been bresking out in hives since march, been on steroids for what is now my third round, and ive had lip swelling as well, so my doctor gave me some epi pens to carry at all times, as I am at increased risk of anaphylaxis. My doctor basically has me under house arrest until I see him again. I am tl stay indoors at all times unless it is an emergency, and I am also to avoid heat and cannot drive, because one of the meds he prescribed me mskes me VERY sleepy when I take it, and I have to take 1 every meal and 2 at bed time. Kind of a bummer just KNOWING I can't get out and do anything, but I also must not lose sight that I am still more fortunate than a great many people are. Here's to a fantastic Independence Day to everyone, and I hope to see more snd more people join "The Zero Club". This is perhaps the only test anyone wants to make a zero on!!

Posts.Content: Hate to hear you have auch aggressive disease. Like the others said, the sooner you begin chemo, the better. While it is a very serious foe you zre dealing with, I would still have hope, because you just don't know. Many, many people have had metastatic disease, that by the textbook, only get worse, however in their resp3ctive cases, they did have successful response to treatment, and they did have sevrral, several years of good quality of life, despite their disease. To me, if cancer can be controlled for several years, and therr is still good quality of life, then that is almost as good as full blown cure.

Posts.Title: Should I start chemo?

Posts.Content: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science...14388215000259 Interesting read on radical prostatectomy for locally advanced prostate cancer that extends outside the prostate gland and up to N1 nodal involvement. This study seems to indicate rather decent success for certain T3 cancers of the prostate. In gleason scores less than or equal to 8, it seems T3a cancers can still have good results when treated with RP and node dissection. Many men get scared if they are diagnosed with T3 disease prior to treatment. The results of this study indicates successful treatment in a significant percentage of men who have RP to treat their locally advanced prostate cancer. SVI involvement does indicate a poorer prognosis advanced and need for additional treatment. But in T3a cancers where it is only outside the capsule, there is fairly good 5 and 10 year overall survival rates when treated with only prostatectomy alone. In short, this further shows that local advancedndredvanced disease is still quite curable for a rest many men. Just something I thought I would share for those who may have this particular kind of prostate cancer. And of course for anyone in this situation, there would still be radiation therapy available to clean anything missed up.

Posts.Content: Interesting gleason grade btw. Signature states 3+5. Typically if there is another pattern present, it's usually just one grade higher than the other, but strange things do happen.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mimi711 Hi all. As soon as we get back to our more normal routines, I plan to write a post about DH's robotic RP which was last week. For now, I have a question regarding lymph nodes. Prior to the surgery, the plan was that the lymph nodes would be sampled with additional nodes to be removed if they looked enlarged. Right after the surgery, DH's surgeon told me that there weren't many lymph nodes there, that there was a lot of fatty tissue on one side, but that he did sample the nodes. The post-op pathology report states that two lymph nodes were removed, one from the right side and one from the left. The report describes the specimen labeled "left pelvic lymph node" but then states: "Sectioning reveals unremarkable adipose tissue, no lymph node grossly is identified." It looks as if the surgeon intended to take out a lymph node from the left side but ended up only with fatty tissue. So where are the lymph nodes on that side? We meet with the surgeon later today and I'm not sure what to ask. Has anyone else had this happen? More importantly, should we be concerned, given the size and how close it was to the capsule, that no lymph node sampling was done on that one side? There had to be lymph nodes there, somewhere, right? Thanks, Mimi Here are relevant parts from the path report: Robotic RP on Aug 20, 2014: still 3+4=7 (whew!) Moderately involved, bilaterally, 25% -EPE; -SVI; +PNI; (intraprostatic); -Lymph node Pseudocapsule penetrated but not capsule itself Each person is different, and locations of lymphnodes arr pribably not the exacf same for everyone. Given that it was negative for extraprostatic extension, negative for seminal vessicle involvement, and negative for the node that was sampled, I wouldn't worry myself sick over it. Chances are still very much in favor thst the surgeon "got it all". Just keep up with the PSA tests post op that are to come. As long as they come out as zero, or undetectable according to the physician, then he should be in good shape, even if they didnt find the other nodes they intended to examine. If the PSA should rise on consecutive readings, there are several options still available with the intent for cure. Salvage radiation being probably the gold standard for that scenario. But again, as long as those PSA tests show "zero" or "undetectable, then your husband is considered prostate cancer free.

Posts.Title: "Lymph node" is all adipose, so NO sampling done on left side?!?

Posts.Content: I agree with dayglo. It's never a bad idea to get a second opinion on biopsies. If you do get another opinion and it is Gleason 6 in that pathologist's opinion, you can take the route of active surveillance and not have to go through treatment. Just keep an eye on that PSA, and if it does not rise, then awesome, nothing needs to be done at that time. If it does rise on subsequent test(s) then you may need to seek treatment. Gleason 6 is the mildest form of prostate cancer. Some even say it's so indolent that it does not have the ability to readily grow and spread. Many Gleason 6 cancers have been present for years, never producing symptoms or evidence of growth because it is such a low grade. Your PSA, tumor quantification, and Gleason score make you a prime candidate for AS. Saving you from side effects and potential complications of treatment. If one has a choice Gleason 6 is definitely the one you "want". Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Aloysius Thanks, Chuck. There's a following statement: (No loss of tumor suppressor). Therefore this adenocarcinoma is slightly more aggressive than the usual Gleason 3+3=6 adenocarcinoma. This isn't the place I want to see the word aggressive......... I don't want to scare you, but from the sound of it, it could be a gleason 7 cancer. That's not neccessarily terrible, particularly if the primary pattern is 3 and the secondary pattern is 4. Perhaps you should ask for your biopsy specimens to be sent to a different pathologists for a second opinion, or perhaps after about 6 weeks you could have a repeat biopsy done and see what those results tell you. I'm not familiar with the terms "ERG" and "PTen" , in fact this is the first time I have seen those two terms, so sadly I can't offer much help there.

Posts.Title: Another Newbie

Posts.Content: HI there, sorry to hear about your family'so battles with cancer, and your own diagnosis. I lost my mother to stage IV squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue base. June 7th will be 9 years. Regarding your case, it sounds like there is likely a decent amount of tumor inside the gland. Lots of positive cores with some exhibiting a primary pattern of 4, this certainly warrants treatment. You are in good health and not suffering from comorbidities that might affect treatment and side effects (Diabetes, heart disease, respiratory disease, or other metabolic disorders.). As my dad's surgeon said, there is no universal treatment that must be followed exclusively, all treatment choices are patient dependent and depends on their preferences, and their particular cancer. Having gleason pattern 4 is an indicator for treatment rather than active surveillance in a healthy man such as yourself. Surgical treatment is a good option, and so is radiation for localized disease. When done by experienced surgeons and radiation oncologists, success rates are quite similar. The fact that the surgeon you are seeing has done over 1000 of these robotic prostatectomy es is very good. He is well versed and experienced, and this greatly reduces chances of unwanted side affects and surgical complications. Sounds like your pathologist who reviewed your slides is quite experienced in that field, so his findings are likely correct, though a second opinion never hurts should you decide to get one. Cure, continence, erectile function are the goals as stated above, and in that particular order. You definitely want to be cured of the disease, and definitely want to avoid continence issues as much as possible. Erectile function comes in third, as it's not quite of the level of importance as the other two, but still is something you want to preserve as much as possible. Given your age and health, going with a well experienced physician, I think you should do quite well. Side effects should be minimal and I think you will have a good outcome, with the ultimate goal of eradication of the cancer.

Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: I agree with highlander on the idea of G6 not evolving into higher gradd cancer, and as he alluded to, if higher grade disease was found upon SURGICAL patholofy, it is likely that grade disease was there to begin with, biopsy just didn't find it because a biopsy only samples a very small portion of the gland. Having said that, I wouldn't say it is impossible for cancers such as 4+3=7 prostate cancer, as they exhibit traits of furthrr dedifferintiation, and one can think by further dedifferenation, then perhaps indeed this kind of cancer could perhaps evolve into fulminant G8 disease, and perhaps higher if not treated promptly. G6 cancers still have quite a bit of resemblance to normal cells, you can still make out fairly easily what cells are glandular in nature, and other cells arising from othrr etiolgy, such as squamous cells which make up the lining of pretty much all of the body's organs and major tissues. And thus, being able to easily tell these cells apart means they are well differentiated, and less aggressive than cancers that are not as well differintiated.

Posts.Title: A Way Point on the Journey - First Post

Posts.Content: My dad had a "rise" in January to 0.13 from 0. Checked again in May, it was 0.1, and checked again 3 days ago, and it was zero again. When they go to retest your husband's, it may very well turn up as zero or undetectable, which would certainly be good. Current guidelines state that for BCR to be declared the PSA must read 0.2 or higher on at least two consecutive tests. And at 0.014, your husband is quite far from that. uPSA assays can cause anxiety from fluctuations like that, and as such, many urologists don't like to use the ultrasensative assay. Given that the margin was Gleason 3, and assuming the total Gleason score was 6, I am highly doubtful he would experience BCR. Gleason 6/pattern 3 they say cannot survive outside the prostate. It lacks the malignant potential to grow outside the confines of the gland. Take a deep breath, I think your husband will be just fine.

Posts.Title: Got Something I did NOT want today! Rise in PSA

Posts.Content: Yikes, hate to hear you have locally advanced prostate cancer, but glad to see the response you had to therapy per your PSA tests.The bone scans being negative and the lymph turning out benign is certainly good. You still have a good shot at cure. Gleason 9 is indeed a nasty cancer, but fortunately your bone scans were negative, and the lymph nodes taken were also negative. When prostate cancer spreads, these are the first places it will go. The lymphatic system is one of the major ways that cancer of any type spreads, and for reasons I don't know,prostate cancer has a preference for bones when it spreads. So the fact both your bones and the sampled nodes we're negative is a very good sign. I'm guessing that when you say another shot, you are referring to another attempt at removing the prostate right? It isn't common for doctors to do prostatectomies after radiation, as there is scar tissue formation that makes it harder to remove the gland, but a good experienced surgeon can indeed work around this. And T3 disease can still be eradicated via surgery.
Posts.Title: Newcomer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Another thing to remember is that, although most of us (myself, included) forget that technically the prostate is NOT the only gland that produces PSA. The two Cowper's Glands at the base of the penis (that produce the slick, clear "pre-cum fluid," also produce very tiny amounts of PSA. At least I recall reading this recently. In most cases, these two pea sized glands are spared during radical prostatectomy. In fact, in my case, they still produce that fluid and provides me with "wet" orgasms most of the time. Thus,these two glands probably account for -- at least in part -- the microfluxiations that might be present in the supersensitive PSA tests. Mayo says the supersensitive test causes too much unnecessary anxiety. But, as Jim notes, there are situations where it probably can be valuable in certain cases. Chuck That is an excellent point on the cowpers glands, those seem to be overlooked in the vast majority of cases, but that is definirely something people should besr in mind. A tiny rise in psa post treatment, as you said, may just simply be a result of the cowpers glands releasing extremely small amounts of psa, so as long as a rise in psa isn't all that significant, it is likely the product od the cowpers glands. As far as the ultrasensative PSA test, I too believe it can cause unwarranted anxieties in a lot of men, a small rise detected by this tsst might just be due to the cowpers glands. However, I do believe it has some value, particularly in higher grade cancers such as gleason 7(4+3). In these higher grade cancers, the ultrasensative PSA can perhaps(in my theory anyway) detect the signs of possible biochemical recurrence/failure at an earlier time and can therefore lead to retreatment and achieve better results, rhan if perhaps using the standard one decimal place test. As we all know, the sooner anything is detected, the better, including possible disease recurrence.This is all of course just my opinion and theory based on what ive read about prostate cancer, and it should not be used in the stead of trained physician advice. I really do think the ultrasensative psa test can be of benefit for men that had treatment of aggressive prostate cancer, though.

Posts.Title: Question about PSA testing methods

Posts.Content: I have been wondering which test is the best for PSA testing post treatment, specifically following prostatectomy. As you all know from my posts, my dad's PSA since the surgery have all been undetectable, AKA zero. That being said I often womder what is the better method to use. The standard PSA test that uses one decimal place, or thd ultrasensative test that uses two decimal places. My dad's PSA has been under 0.04 since the operation. His surgeon uses two "less than" signs on my dad's specific case. PSA <<0.04 . Is the ultrsensative psa test designed to detect ANY level of psa that is detectable, and what do the double less than signs mean? I do not believe the extra less than sign to be a typo. Oh and my dad's most recent PSA test in April was still <<0.04 ng/mL I may have already mentioned that but can't remember. He goes back August 19th for his next PSA test, so he is now on an every 4 month schedule instead of the every three month schedule he was on last year, which I take to be a good thing.

Posts.Title: Question about PSA testing methods

Posts.Content: I agree with highlander on the idea of G6 not evolving into higher gradd cancer, and as he alluded to, if higher grade disease was found upon SURGICAL patholofy, it is likely that grade disease was there to begin with, biopsy just didn't find it because a biopsy only samples a very small portion of the gland. Having said that, I wouldn't say it is impossible for cancers such as 4+3=7 prostate cancer, as they exhibit traits of furthrr dedifferintiation, and one can think by further dedifferenation, then perhaps indeed this kind of cancer could perhaps evolve into fulminant G8 disease, and perhaps higher if not treated promptly. G6 cancers still have quite a bit of resemblance to normal cells, you can still make out fairly easily what cells are glandular in nature, and other cells arising from othrr etiolgy, such as squamous cells which make up the lining of pretty much all of the body's organs and major tissues. And thus, being able to easily tell these cells apart means they are well differentiated, and less aggressive than cancers that are not as well differintiated.

Posts.Title: Newcomer

Posts.Content: HI there, sorry to hear about your family'so battles with cancer, and your own diagnosis. I lost my mother to stage IV squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue base. June 7th will be 9 years. Regarding your case, it sounds like there is likely a decent amount of tumor inside the gland. Lots of positive cores with some exhibiting a primary pattern of 4, this certainly warrants treatment. You are in good health and not suffering from comorbidities that might affect treatment and side effects (Diabetes, heart disease, respiratory disease, or other metabolic disorders.). As my dad's surgeon said, there is no universal treatment that must be followed exclusively, all treatment choices are patient dependent and depends on their preferences, and their particular cancer. Having gleason pattern 4 is an indicator for treatment rather than active surveillance in a healthy man such as yourself. Surgical treatment is a good option, and so is radiation for localized disease. When done by experienced surgeons and radiation oncologists, success rates are quite similar. The fact that the surgeon you are seeing has done over 1000 of these robotic prostatectomy es is very good. He is well versed and experienced, and this greatly reduces chances of unwanted side affects and surgical complications. Sounds like your pathologist who reviewed your slides is quite experienced in that field, so his findings are likely correct, though a second opinion never hurts should you decide to get one. Cure, continence, erectile function are the goals as stated above, and in that particular order. You definitely want to be cured of the disease, and definitely want to avoid continence issues as much as possible. Erectile function comes in third, as it's not quite of the level of importance as the other two, but still is something you want to preserve as much as possible. Given your age and health, going with a well experienced physician, I think you should do quite well. Side effects should be minimal and I think you will have a good outcome, with the ultimate goal of eradication of the cancer.

Posts.Content: Well my father has decided to go ahead with an operation to repair a hernia at the incision site where the prostate was removed. This doctor said it likely happened because the muscle there is likely still weak and will need extra reinforcement, so he is going to put in 2 meshes. He said he sees this a lot in his clinic after patients have had robotic operations. I am very worried about this surgery due to dad having blood clots following his RALP, but he said they will take every preventive measure they can to reduce the risk of it happening again. I believe the biggest reason he got the clots to begin with was because the nurses failed to utilize the compression device as he stayed overnight. They had it hooked up, but apparently did not have it actively compressing or improperly hooked up and dysfunctional. Of course at the time we were only thinking about the cancer being removed, did not think much of clots. But in hindaight, I believe this was the cause of the clots. I'm really ner ous about this one, but the doc said it will take 30-45 minutes and thus the less time under anaesthesia, the less the risk of such complication. He said he does not like the robotic approach because it is longer in duration and riskier in his opinion.

Id say as an uneducated, layman's guess, the single decimal psa test probably would be sufficient for those wth confirmed g6 disease, as g6 is pretty easily treated and curable. G7 or higher on the other hand, the ultra sensative psa test would likely be more suitable, as it can detect even the slightest rise in psa, and thus prompt additional treatment if required.

Posts.Content: That is great news that you are getting to take part in the clin8cal trial, and are in the treatment arm of the trial. I would say surgery to remove a cancerous prostate with just one bone met would prove beneficial. I'm no Dr, but to remove the primary tumor would be a good idea in a case like yours. Less cancer is always good. And who knows, perhaps doing such would slow development of new metastasis. Certainly seems worth a shoot in my book. The last 4 lines of your signature are encouraging as it indicates a PSA that has fallen dramatically with Lupron all the way to 4.1 from a high of 62.4. Great response!! And the fact the met doesn't appear on the last scan is quite encouraging as well. I think you've got a good shot at controiling this animal for several years.

Posts.Title: Got Something I did NOT want today! Rise in PSA

Posts.Content: My dad had a "rise" in January to 0.13 from 0. Checked again in May, it was 0.1, and checked again 3 days ago, and it was zero again. When they go to retest your husband's, it may very well turn up as zero or undetectable, which would certainly be good. Current guidelines state that for BCR to be declared the PSA must read 0.2 or higher on at least two consecutive tests. And at 0.014, your husband is quite far from that. uPSA assays can cause anxiety from fluctuations like that, and as such, many urologists don't like to use the ultrasensative assay. Given that the margin was Gleason 3, and assuming the total Gleason score was 6, I am highly doubtful he would experience BCR. Gleason 6/pattern 3 they say cannot survive outside the prostate. It lacks the malignant potential to grow outside the confines of the gland. Take a deep breath, I think your husband will be just fine.

Posts.Title: Got Something I did NOT want today! Rise in PSA

Posts.Content: Excellent news, the longer you go without a detectable PSA the more likely it is the treatment exterminated the cancer, snd the less likely it is to come back. That 1 year mark post treatment disease free is a huge milestone, as is the 18 month mark. Keep those good reports coming!! While there are serious risks to surgery, on the whole the chances of major complications sre quite low. My dad was the exception to that, but certainly not the general rule of what to expect post treatment. He did indeed suffer blood clots, which was a risk the doctor told him was possible, and they broke off to form pulmonary emboli, which lwnded him in sicu for a couple nights and a 5 day overall stay in the hospital. He is also permanently incontinent, but he feels part of that may be because he wasnt doing his kegel excercises properly. Even though all this happened to my dad, the overall risk for rhese complications is still quite low, it just so happened my dad wound up being one of the 5% who do have serious complications.

Posts.Title: Question about fPSA number??

Posts.Content: Hello. Free PSA is the percentage of PSA that has not binded to other chemicals in the blood. The lower the percentage of free PSA, the greater the chance of prostate cancer being present. Your psa rising is concerning and definitely needs to be investigated. It does not mean you have prostate cancer but does mean it is possible. Only a biopsy can diagnose prostate cancer. Psa can be elevated to benign conditions such as enlargement of the prostate and prostatits. Your doctor will almost certify want to do a DRE and a biopsy. He will feel for lumps and bumps, and check for firmness. Any of these present raises concern. A biopsy will sample a certain amount of "cores",usually 12, though sometimes more or less. They would then be examined under microscope and any abnormalities noted, and if cancer cells are present, they will estimate how much of each core is cancerous and a Gleason grade will be given based on how any cancerous cells look. If they look fairly uniform, and show good glandular formation, they'll be assigned a lower Gleason score. If they do not look unkform, appear haphqzard, and less glandular formation seen, they will be assigned a higher Gleason score. Hopefully you won't have cancer and your psa will be related to benign conditions. If you do get diagnosed wth prostate cqncer, note that prostate cancer is typically slow growing and may not require treatment right away. Many, many men live with low gfade disease that does not threaten their life, and many die from something else other than their cancer. Even if prostate cancer escapes the gland, survival is still good, and cure can still be achievedone as long as it doesn't get to far from the prostate. Let us know how everything goes.

Posts.Title: PSA recurrence

Posts.Content: Thanks for your input Jim, and I am sorry that you have had to deal with PC as well. My dad is now 67 and the Dr considered everything reading less than the 0.04 mark to be zero. I just saw something that said for it to be determined to be a true recurrence that the PSAmerican after surgical removal has to be 0.2 ng/ml or above on at least two successive tests. It also said that in many cases, even if there is a recurrence, often times it is on a microscopic level and may not become clinically or visibly evident for several years. He has stated that he has had a lot of trouble going to the bathroom, bowel movements, but urination is ok. So with the troubles with BM, that raises much concern to me. Though it should be noted he's had issues with his colon as well, and this isn't the first time he's had issues with BMW, he does have divermiculite which has caused issues with BM as well. It's just the proximity to the prostate bed and colon that leads me to worry additionally about a possible recurrence. I'm really hoping this morning'so test result was a sampling error, and the next one returns back to the usual <0.04 that his physician's lab defines as zero or undetectable.

Posts.Title: Question about fPSA number??

Posts.Content: That is outstanding. To be faced with such a dire prognosis with the widespread metastases, and now 12 years later, still no signs of disease progression and your PSA still being essentially undetectable; that alone is just amazing, especially taking into account where the mets went to and how many there were. But now you are even GAINING libido and your function is returning, that is just really something else. That is the cherry on top right there. You are a penultimate example for men with advanced, and even metastatic prostate cancer to never give up. Super stoked for you that you have been able to beat back such a demon and that you are having quality of life in the process. Truly remarkable. I am really happy for you. Heres to a couple more decades of similar results. Take care.

Posts.Title: 12 years

Posts.Content: Hello. Free PSA is the percentage of PSA that has not binded to other chemicals in the blood. The lower the percentage of free PSA, the greater the chance of prostate cancer being present. Your psa rising is concerning and definitely needs to be investigated. It does not mean you have prostate cancer but does mean it is possible. Only a biopsy can diagnose prostate cancer. Psa can be elevated to benign conditions such as enlargement of the prostate and prostatits. Your doctor will almost certify want to do a DRE and a biopsy. He will feel for lumps and bumps, and check for firmness. Any of these present raises concern. A biopsy will sample a certain amount of "cores",usually 12, though sometimes more or less. They would then be examined under microscope and any abnormalities noted, and if cancer cells are present, they will estimate how much of each core is cancerous and a Gleason grade will be given based on how any cancerous cells look. If they look fairly uniform, and show good glandular formation, they'll be assigned a lower Gleason score. If they do not look unkform, appear haphqzard, and less glandular formation seen, they will be assigned a higher Gleason score. Hopefully you won't have cancer and your psa will be related to benign conditions. If you do get diagnosed wth prostate cqncer, note that prostate cancer is typically slow growing and may not require treatment right away. Many, many men live with low gfade disease that does not threaten their life, and many die from something else other than their cancer. Even if prostate cancer escapes the gland, survival is still good, and cure can still be achievedone as long as it doesn't get to far from the prostate. Let us know how everything goes.

Posts.Content: Hi all, been a while since I last posted. For a refresher, my dad had his prostate removed April 23 2013, had cancer in both lobes of the prostate, was stage t2c, Gleason 6 with one margin containing what was said to be "focal minimal involvement". Up till now his PSA had been 0, but this morning he had a scheduled test and it came back an alarming 0.13. Dr wants to retest in 4 months and go from there. Why is he waiting so long gone? What, if anything can be done if it is indeed back? I am freaking out.

Posts.Content: Thanks for your input Jim, and I am sorry that you have had to deal with PC as well. My dad is now 67 and the Dr considered everything reading less than the 0.04 mark to be zero. I just saw something that said for it to be determined to be a true recurrence that the PSAmerican after surgical removal has to be 0.2 ng/ml or above on at least two successive tests. It also said that in many cases, even if there is a recurrence, often times it is on a microscopic level and may not become clinically or visibly evident for several years. He has stated that he has had a lot of trouble going to the bathroom, bowel movements, but urination is ok. So with the troubles with BM, that raises much concern to me. Though it should be noted he's had issues with his colon as well, and this isn't the first time he's had issues with BMW, he does have divermiculite which has caused issues with BM as well. It's just the proximity to the prostate bed and colon that leads me to worry additionally about a possible recurrence. I'm really hoping this morning'so test result was a sampling error, and the next one returns back to the usual <0.04 that his physician's lab defines as zero or undetectable.

Posts.Content: I agree with the others, a biopsy is the best thing to do to give you the best clinical picture possible. They aren't perfect, as they can miss areas of cancer, or areas of more aggressive cancer, but they are usually correct in most cases. You said your PSA went up to 5 and back down to 3.8. Sounds like some poteial inflammation/prostatitis going on in there. An enlarged prostate is quite possible too. The older you get, the larger the prostate tends to get. Enlarged prostates can raise psa. It is also possible on the flip side there may be some cancer there. My dad had a PSA of 4.2 with an enlarged prostate, and biopsy revealed gleason 6 in 5/12 cores. The biopsy itself isn't that bad. The Dr will anesthetize the area, and give you aneed antibiotic to take before and after the procedure just to safeguard in the unlikely hood of infection. If you are anxious, he or she may give something like a Valium or low dose Xanax before the procedure to relax you. They gave my dad Valium before his biopsy and he was pretty well chill during and after the procedure. 15 minutes or so and it's done.

Posts.Title: Options aside from a biopsy?

Posts.Content: That is outstanding. To be faced with such a dire prognosis with the widespread metastases, and now 12 years later, still no signs of disease progression and your PSA still being essentially undetectable; that alone is just amazing, especially taking into account where the mets went to and how many there were. But now you are even GAINING libido and your function is returning, that is just really something else. That is the cherry on top right there. You are a penultimate example for men with advanced, and even metastatic prostate cancer to never give up. Super stoked for you that you have been able to beat back such a demon and that you are having quality of life in the process. Truly remarkable. I am really happy for you. Heres to a couple more decades of similar results. Take care.

Posts.Title: 12 years

Posts.Content: Thanks for your input Jim, and I am sorry that you have had to deal with PC as well. My dad is now 67 and the Dr considered everything reading less than the 0.04 mark to be zero. I just saw something that said for it to be determined to be a true recurrence that the PSAmerican after surgical removal has to be 0.2 ng/ml or above on at least two successive tests. It also said that in many cases, even if there is a recurrence, often times it is on a microscopic level and may not become clinically or visibly evident for several years. He has stated that he has had a lot of trouble going to the bathroom, bowel movements, but urination is ok. So with the troubles with BM, that raises much concern to me. Though it should be noted he's had issues with his colon as well, and this isn't the first time he's had issues with BMW, he does have divermiculite which has caused issues with BM as well. It's just the proximity to the prostate bed and colon that leads me to worry additionally about a possible recurrence. I'm really hoping this morning'so test result was a sampling error, and the next one returns back to the usual <0.04 that his physician's lab defines as zero or undetectable.

Posts.Title: PSA recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi all, been a while since I last posted. For a refresher, my dad had his prostate removed April 23 2013, had cancer in both lobes of the prostate, was stage t2c, Gleason 6 with one margin containing what was said to be "focal minimal involvement". Up till now his PSA had been 0, but this morning he had a scheduled test and it came back an alarming 0.13. Dr wants to retest in 4 months and go from there. Why is he waiting so long gone? What, if anything can be done if it is indeed back? I am freaking out.

Posts.Title: SBRT and hormone therapy

Posts.Content: Hello there. Hate to read that your husband was siagnosed with prostate cancer, but at least on biopsy, it was not a terribly aggressive cancer. The pattern 4 component usually knocks people out of qualification fir Active Surveillance, so getting it treated was a good move. Gleason 3+4, wh8le not nearly as bad as gleason 8, or even 4+3, still does have the ability to metastasize thanks to the pattern 4, but fortunately, it takes it a while to do so, if it ever does. That said, i think the chance of treatment success in his case is very good, and he should do quite well. However, that psa doubling is rather concerning, especially the jump from 6 to 12 in such a short time. It COULD be possible there was some higher grade like 4+3 or gleason 8 in there, but only the pathologist can determine that by looking at the whole specimen. The doctor usually gets the pathology report back in about a week, and then he or she can discuss the true status of the disease in detail. He or she can tell you then if there was higher grade cancer present or not, ehether or not it broke through the capsule (extraprostatic extension), whether or not it invaded the seminal vesiclea, and if any lymph nodes were sampled, that can tell whether or not the cancer spread to the lymphnodes. And it can tell if the margins were positive or negative. Negative means no cancer cells were seen involving the cut plane, whereas positive would mean there was some cancer invading into the cut plane. Often times, even if margins are positive, its insignificant because it cut through the tumor in the gland, and with no gland, those cancerous cells at the margin cannot survive, and they die, depending on just how much of the margin was involved. And by having surgery, that means radiation therapy would still be available as a curative treatment in the unlikelihood that it comes back down the road. But rest assured, with a skilled surgeon,the likelihood that they "got it all" is quite high, and the more skilled the surgeon is, the more likely they can spare the nerves, helpinh to keep sexual function intact, and continence issues can be minimized. The goals of treatment are as follows in order of most important to least: 1. Cancer cure 2. Continence 3. Preservation of sexual function. Let us know what the pathology report says, and then in.about 3 months, he should get his first post op psa, that will be vital for treatment success. A post op PSA test is about the only test i can think of that the goal is to make a "zero", in which case it's considered a success, and the patient is considered free of prostate cancer. Best Wishes.

Posts.Content: As the others have said, there are treatment regimens available rhat can prolong life for several more years and provide good symptom control to go along with it. Of course any of this would ultimately come down to your father's wishes. But a good discussion with specialist in prostate cancer wouldn't be a bad idea, as they can let your father know about trewtments from which he could satisfactorily benefit from. Hate to hear it is stage 4, but that by no means indicates he has to give up on treating it. There are clinical trials out there as well that are showing encouraging results.

Posts.Title: New here, Prostectomy complete

Posts.Content: Hi there, if you had to get cancer, this one would be the least of all the evils. Gleason 6, less than 3 positive cores, and such s small percentage makes active syrveillance a hreat choice for you. Gleason 6 has never killed anybody that i know of, and doednt even hsve the ability to metastasize to lymphnodes. So actuve syrveillance is a hreat and prudent choice here. You get to avoid the side effects that come with treatment. Of courde with it being just a biopsy sample, there is no guarantee there isnt higher grade disease in there somewhere, but actuve surveillance does involve periodic testing, and that can pick up on potential signs there might be something more lurking in there. But for now, you dont have to worry about treatment, and you can go about your daily business as usual. And always, we are here to give advice and answer questions that you msy hsve. Lots of knowledgeable people here, so you are certainly in a good place. Long as that PSA remains low, and furure DREs remain normal, you wont have to worry about syarting treatment sny time soon, if at all. Best regards.

Posts.Title: My story, currently.

Posts.Content: Hi, i am very sorry to hear that your father has such a nasty form and grade of prostate cancer. All is nkt lost however. You said his imaging studies show widespread metastases, with some in the pelvis essentially coalescing into one big, nasty blob of tumor in his pelvis. But his PSA has fallen from 30 to way down to .02, now THAT is an impressive responsevand treatment effect. To see shch bulk amount of cancer respond so dramatically is veey, very impressive, and is just indicative of very effective treatment. Him still being physically active is a favorably prognosticator, at least in the short term. It cannot be cured, but it CAN be controlled, as evidenced by the current response. This can be managed for possibly a long time before it becomes refractory to treatment. Best wishes Brandon

Posts.Title: Gleason 10 with next to no PSA detected

Posts.Content: Hello there, that is quite an enlarged gland indeed, and surgery was a good choice of treatment. It would seem as I understand it, they found some gleason 6 cancers included inthere as well. Good news is, Gleason 6 is on the lowest end of the prostate cancer spectrum. Surgery pretty much always cures it, and I have scoured the Internet looking for possible metastatic gleason 6 cancers, and not one article could I find that mentioned such a finding. In fact, every article I did find all agreed that Gleason 6 really lacks the ability to metastasize, and thus is not considered a threat to a man's life. The cases in which g6 diagnosed at biopsy that did extend outside the gland, or into lymphnodes, etc, every single one of them had some amount of pattern 4 present, and those turned out to be 4+3=7 cancers. Your psa being under 10, and heck, in the normal range, us your G6 bodes excellent for you. I would imagine any scans done will turn up negative for prostate cancer. I think you are in excellent shape.

Posts.Title: psa question

Posts.Content: Its hard to say. It pribably depends on each individual person. Some recover quicker than others. My dad took a while to regain good contienence. Hes about 99% continent now, and only has issues doing strenuous activity (steel worker). But other than that, he doesnt experience issues. Be sure to do those kegel excercises, they'll help tremendously in regaining continence. It strengthens the sphincter and bladder muscles.

Posts.Title: Nerve sparing surgery and incontinence

Posts.Content: Hi there, hopefully you will not have to "join the club", but should that time come, this forum is a treasure cove of knowledge and advice. I see in your signature that the DRE estimates your gland to be 25 grams. That is a normal size prostate. Whatever that tells me I'm a man your age is that there is quite possibly some inflammation going on in there, ie prostatitis, this can raise psa levels a couple of points. One general rule of thumb I have heard some Dr's use is "it ain't cancer unless it is diagnosed and confirmed to be such". The PSA rising is a bit concerning, but again, this could be due to prostatitis, a fairly common occurrence in men over age 50. But a biopsy is the only thing right now that can give us a concrete idea of what's going on, sans-serif having the gland removed. Prostate biopsies while perhaps seemingly daunting, are not really that bad. Your Dr will be sure to anesthetize the area well, so as to minimalist any pain or discomfort. He or she will likely also give you a couple antibiotic pills to take before and after the procedure to safeguard against the low chance of post biopsy infection. He or she may also give you a benzodiazapine such as Valium to help you relax, that's what my dad's urologist did anyway, and he was pretty chill throughout the process. You might experience some soreness following the procedure, and you might have minor blood in the urine for a couple days afterward, but this is normal, nothing to worry about, and doesn't always happen. You might hear some clipping noises during the procedure, and that is simply the tool taking snippets or little "cores" of prostate tissue to be examined. Best wishes, and let us know what your biopsy report says.

Posts.Title: New to all of this

Posts.Content: I am happy to report that my dad has made another zero on the PSA test. He is now just 6 months Way from the 5 year mark in which most doctors consider the official cured threshold. The Dr said if it returns as zero then as he expects it to, he will readily and happily use that "other" c word--CURED!! Thought I'd share the good news and provide an update. Had that scare in January when it read .13, but I asked th3 Dr today about that, and he said that was a sampling or machine error.

Posts.Title: New to all of this

Posts.Content: Hmm, Gleason 8 is unfortunately a rather aggressive disease. I'm not sure why the DR is not ordering bone scans. Not saying this to scare you, but when prostate cancer metastasizes, it tends to favor the bones. Gleason 8 is a high risk cancer, and I would think it prudent to run bone scans just to make sure there are no bone Mets present. Do you have a copy of his biopsy report, or can you request one from the Dr office? That contains key information, and can help stratification a man's risk into the probability of having/not having disease outside of the prostate gland. The biopsy report would tell you the number of cores positive for cancer, a how much of each core was involved by cancer. You did state you think his PSA to be 12, which is on the high side, but I've seen much higher from folks here and heard of some insanely high psa level. The MRI could perhaps identify areas of tumor activity in the prostate, and the CT could perhaps be looking to see if any cancer is present in tissues around the prostate. Let us know what you find out.

Posts.Title: Dad's PSA is still 0!!!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo Congrats! You and especially your dad had enough "excitement" in 2013. Here's wishing for a nice, quiet, uneventful, "Zero-Club" 2014! Thanks!! Yeah that's putting it mildly. In retrospect, the blood clots caused more harm than the cancer did, and at times, that made me think we made a mistake going with surgery. However, I now believe the decision to have surgery was a sound idea, as it gives the doctor an actual view of the prostate, and the pathologist the opportunity to find the true grade and extent of the disease. Whereas with radiation, brachytherapy, or AS, it is more of an educated guess, which sometimes hits it spot on, and misses in other cases. For this reason, I would consider myself a "surgery guy" like highlander when it comes to prostate cancer that is organ confined.

Posts.Title: Dad's PSA is still 0!!!

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, hope all is well, it has been a while since my last post, but i come with great news. My dad had his PSA checked this past monday, and it was once again 0. Officially <0.04 ng/mL. He now only has to get it checked on a yearly basis, and has the option to come in at any time of his choosing should he want it checked sooner than that. Doctors are very tight lipped when using the words cured and cancer in the same sentence, but the urologist was very blunt and not hestitant in saying "Congratulations Mr. O'tinger, your PSA on our test today is once again 0, and this is your 5th year of 0 PSA after your surgery, so it is with great pleasure that I declare you cured of your prostate cancer." It is almost hard to believe it has already been 5 years since the diagnosis and treatment. Had a rough go of it in the initial post operativve phase with the DVTs in his legs and the resulting pulmonary emboli that sent him to SICU for a few days, and the months of blood thinner that followed. It took him roughly 2 years to recovery completely from that. But now, all is well, and we can celebrate the fact he is now a 5 year cancer survivor, a mark that sadly many others do not reach. Here is to hoping that the rest of you who are battling prostate cancer, or know someone who is, can also reach that big milestone, and live a happy and fulfilled life.

Posts.Title: Officially 5 years free of prostate cancer for dad

Posts.Content: Perineural invasion in prostate cancer that is low grade seems to be a topic that has different arguments. It has been said in many cases that PNI in low grade disease is not terribly significant, but I've also read online that PNI can perhaps turn an otherwise indolent prostate cancer into somewhat of a higher risk disease. These perineural spaces run through and out of the prostate through microscopic holes in the capsule. And it has been mentioned that even with Gleason 6 disease, the presence of perineural invasion may warrant a more proactive approach, as from what I've read, prostate cancer can travel along these perineural spaces and exit the prostate and perhaps spread locally, ie to seminal vesicles and nearby tissues, such as fat. Perhaps this doesn't make Gleason 6 wit perineural invasion present a particularly high risk, but a somewhat greater risk than Gleason 6 with no perineural invasion present. My dad had expressed regret over surgery due to the blood clots, and incontinence issues. But from what I read about prostate cancer utilizing perineural spaces to perhaps escape the gland, I'm still glad he had it done, I didn't want him to take any chances (not to mention having confirmation of true Gleason 6 on his surgical pathology;as many people are found to have higher grade disease). What are your takes on this topic? Does presence of perineural invasion on biopsy make active surveillance less likely for men with Gleason 6 prostate cancer?

Posts.Title: Treatment or Otherwise

Posts.Content: Hi, i posted my dad's last PSA result, and it was 0, as we hoped, but alas, didn't truly get to enjoy it right away. Couple days after that, he started having flu symptoms, this keot going on for several days until sunday, December 3rd, he was so weak he couldn't stand without a walker. Immediately went to urgent care dacility that day, where he had a high grade fever of 104.3 and some hypoxia, O2 sat was 87/88% on room air. He wss then taken to x ray, where they did an anterior and lateral view. Both views showed significant opacity in the right middle, and right lower lobes of his right lung. He was then put on oxygen at 3L at which brought his O2 back to about 93%. Disatisfied with this, the Dr gave us a copy of the visut reoort, and CD of the X ray and told us to go to the ER immediately, as it appeared he had pneumonia and was compromised to some degree in both oxygenation and blood pressure. So we get to the ER, and go up to the registration desk requesting urgent care as suggested by the clinic dr to get him into the ER department quicker. Got triaged and high fever and low saturation and low blood pressure persisted, so we were sent to a room immediately. And not pne of the regular rooms, but the trauma/resuscitation bay-- one that had defibrilators and crash cart already in the room, and significany cooler than the rest of the department, so apparently they felt dad was borderline hemodynamically and respiratoraly unstable. There he had blood draws which revealed a very high WBC of 18.7 with normal.values for their lab being between 6.2 and 10.6. Was also revealed to be quite dehydrated and low on potassium. Urine was tea colored, and potassium was 3. Normal values on that were 3.5 to 5.2, so he was given fluid and 40 mEQ of potassium chloride. He had noted thst his legs from the knee down were in significant pain, which was refractory to tylenol. So based on his answer of 9/10 on the pain scale, ge was given dilaudid over a slow drip. This made him sleep. There, his oxugen improved some after recieving a shpt of rocephin and dekasol. Was 95% on 3L of oxygen. He was then hooked up to a telemetry monitor, which covered the usual HR, RR, O2 sat, and BP, with BP raken every 15 mi ures and automatically timed and recorded. We were in this resuscitation room for a good 4 hours. Turns out that though it wss requested he be admitted by his PCP fir inpatient observation, there were no beds available at tge time on the med floor. Finally, ER doctor comes back in and confirms the diagnosis of pneumonia, which had arusen from the flu, and she finally got us ready fir a room. It only became available after a patient died. So after housekeeping had time to clean the room, and gwt new linen, we finally got into the room at 1:12 am, and adnitedly, both of us were a little wary of being in a room and on the very bed where the previous patient had "expired" -- hate it when tgey use that term. To tge best if my kbowledge, we don't spoil like milk...... Anyway, he was given some very strong IV antibiotics, some hydro for his pain, and more fluid to help his hydration status. Nurses were in and put about every 4 hours taking vitals, so it was ratger difficult for us to really rest. They also gave him nebulizer treatments every 4 hours to help open his lung up. Slowly he began to respond to antibiotics, fever was coming down, and he was able to tolerate a lower flow of oxygen and sustain a decent O2. 96% there over the course of the night on 2L instead of 3L of oxygen. Next day showed no change on the x ray, still had opacities in the right middle, and right lower lobe, so he was kept for another night to be observed. Held steady on 02 sats and his temperature finally started to break. At this point, the dr was pleased, and said within 2 days we shpuld get to go home, as his temp inproved and heart rate lowered, and blood pressure stabilized. Dad cpuld have went home the next morni g, but he opted to stay one more day just to be on the safe sude when asked by the Dr. X ray the next morning dhowed slow clearing of the opacities, and with that and improved hydration, good bp, good oxygen on room air, he was finally able to go hone that wednesday, 3 days after admission. Left tge hospital with a 10 day orescription of levoquin 750 mg, and follow up with PCP. Got the follow up visit done and had another x ray done there, and it showrd slow, but continued clearing of the opacities. Ge was then cleared to go back to work the next day, which he did, and hes been hammering away since. Home pulse oximeter shows 97-98% oxygenation now, and he was able to gain his stamina back quickly. Did lose about 12 lbs while he was sick. Now with all that said, we can finally enjoy the 0 PSA and carry on. Just about 6 months or so will be that big 5 year mark, which we certainly look forward to. And we agreed that when ge starts getting sick like that again, he will go to the Dr if hes not any better after 3 days, instead of trying to tough it out. Who knows, if we had waited 1 more day as bad off he was, he might have required ICU admission. And he definitely doesn't want that stuff again and not have to miss several days work, so hes going to go to the Dr a little more promptly tge next time he feels ill. Whew.

Posts.Title: Didn't get to celebrate zero club renewal for a couple weeks

Posts.Content: Absolutely. I'd rather have G6 PNI+, rather than say, G8 without PNI. My dad having it puts me at higher risk myself down the road, so I'll definitely be getting those recommended screenings when I hit 40. I should note that what I read does not say that PNI on G6 disease definitively makes it riskier, though it did say it is possible, but debatable . I just don't see Gleason 6 becoming metastatic disease.
Posts.Title: The topic of perineural invasion and low grade disease.

Posts.Content: Yeah, PNI on surgical pathology is quite frequent, it's just when it's present on biopsy that makes me wonder, since biopsy only samples a very tiny portion of the prostate. If it is found on biopsy, even in Gleason 6, would that make G6 in that case higher risk than G6 without pni. I definitely still think Gleason 6 w/pni is better than a more aggressive cancer without it, g7 4+3 -pni for example. I also still can't imagine a G6 tumor metastasizing. And on a side note, low risk prostate cancer is considered that of Gleason 6 or less, no more than two cores positive, and under a certain percentage of those cores involved with cancer. Though I'm not sure what the cutoff there is. So what should we tell someone with G6 disease with more than 2 cores positive and say for example cores being 40% involved with cancer?
Posts.Title: The topic of perineural invasion and low grade disease.

Posts.Content: I would say your bladder infection is the source of your pains, and enlargement(benign prostatic hyperplasia, bph), inflammation of the prostate(prostatitis) can cause your PSA to be elevated. Prostate cancer is typically slow growing, and most men if they die, do so WITH prostate cancer not BECAUSE of prostate cancer. That being said, you don't need tonworry yourself sick, see what the medicine does first, rule out other conditions before ruling in prostate cancer. A biopsy can tell you about the state of your prostate, and it can find cancer if any is present as well, but because the biopsy only samples a very small portion of the gland, it is possible to miss cancer, or miss higher grade cancer. You have not stated your age, as a general rule of thumb, the older a man gets, the higher the threshold for what is considered a "normal" PSA value becomes since the prostate tends to enlarge with age anyway. A PSA of 4.11 isnt terrible if it is indeed elevated according to age. IF cancer is indeed present, PSA levels under 10ng/mL indicate low grade, organ confined disease, and therefore a very treatable and curable cancer, and depending on factors suchnas gleason score, number of cores positive for cancer on biopsy, immexiate treatment may not be needed, and in fact may even be advised against depending on factors such as age and presence or absence of significant health problems like COPD and heart disease.

Posts.Content: Im afraid I can't really help with most of the subjects at hand. But the gleason score being the kind with grade 4 dominant pattern is probably what enabled it to metastasize. 65% is a significant amount, and there were probably cells around the capsule that extended through it and spread from there. The pattern 4 component is significantly more aggressive than the pattern 3, and sadly, he had more pattern 4 than he did pattern 3. Thats my guess as to why it went metastatic.

Posts.Title: Recent Stage IV Diagnosis

Posts.Content: 8.8 is indeed an elevated psa. And a lump on DRE is suspicious, but not diagnostic. The biopsy will be able to tell what's going on. Many lumps are benign cysts, or products from inflammation of the prostate--prostatitis. It could be cancer, but only a biopsy can determine whether or not you have cancer. They usually take 12 cores on standard biopsies, sometimes they might extract a little more, depending on what the Dr thinks is the best route to go. A PSA of 8.8 can also arise as a result of prostate enlargement, commonly referred as BPH-- benign prostatic hyperplasia. IF the biopsy does turn up positive for cancer, know that there are several treatment options available, and often times, treatment is not required right away, and sometimes it may never be required. Gleason 6 cancers with 3 cores or less positive for cancer makes one for a candidate for active surveillance. If it were to find a higher grade cancer, such as gleason 7, 4+3, then treatment would likely be recommended sooner than later. But again this all hinges on the biopsy and what it finds. Try not to worry.

Posts.Title: Can anyone advise me

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, hope all is well and you all had a happy new year. It has been a while since I last posted , but we are considering sueing my dad's urologist. Not because of the blood clots, but because of the hernia that developed which further set him back and has caused him to go into depression due to not being able to work. The urologist failed to mention that the incision could herniate, and as such, this was not even on our mind as dad considered his treatment options. I just wonder if failure to warn of that possibility can be considered negligence on behalf of the surgeon, and therefore something that we can pursue legal action over. I do not intend to start drama, and if this post does start drama, I sincerely apologize in advance. As we all know, outcomes of surgery rely heavily on the competence and skill of the surgeon. When dad got the news he had prostate cancer, he asked the doctor how many robotic prostatectomies he had done, and the doctor replied "tons of em". That was it, no specific number or estimation, just a vague "tons of em". In hindsight, that should have raised a red flag and perhaps we should have sought advice from another urological surgeon, or even two. I feel they should be able to at least give a ball park estimate of how many procedures they have done. 500 I think, if I read correctly on here and other websites, is the threshold for a doctor to be considered proficient in this kind of operation. The doctor who repaired the hernia(a general surgeon) said that the area did not heal properly, and that left it predisposed to herniating. And he also said he isnt a fan of the robot because of its cost, and said in many cases, it actually takes longer to do than a standard laporoscopic approach. Of course, he could have just been saying that out of bias, but even so, it gave us second thoughts. Whats done is done though, cant go back and undo the operation, but if we had to do it all over again, I think we may have avoided this surgeon and gone with a standard laparoscopic procedure. I doubt we could make a case against the company that made tne robot, as I believe it came down to an error and lackof warning on the doctor's part. He should have been a little more specific when asked how many of these things he has done. It seemed like it offended him slightly when dad asked him.
