Posts.Title: Done with Chemo, Have a couple concerns...

Posts.Content: Yes, as other have said, ask him about the margins, whether they were positive or not, ask him if he sampled any lmphnodes, and if so, ask him what the report shows about them. Ask if extraprostatic extension was present or not, status of the seminal vesicles; whether they were psitive or negative for involvement. And ask him abut the status of the nerve bundles as well. And as far as one core being 4+3 vs the rest of them being Gleason 6, it does supercede the rest of the cores being lower grade. On biopsy such as yours, your cancer I'll be considered 4+3=7 even though the others were Gleason 6. Also keep in mind sometimes on surgical pathology, more aggressive disease is found, this happens around 30% of cases. And in less frequent cases, it can be found to be less agressive tan what the biopsy indicated. At this point the most important factors will be thestatus of the margins, if the are negative, the less likely it is the cancer has spread, Gleason score on the surgical pathology report, and whether or not it involved lymph nodes and/or the seminal vesicles.
Posts.Title: Questions to ask surgeon at pathology report

Posts.Content: Based on the information you've provided, it sounds like your pc is so insignificant that it isn't affecting your psa at all. Just two positive cores, low percentage, and Gleason 6, you are a prime candidate for active surveillance, and you may not ever face problems with your prostate cancer. You can pretty much go about business as if you don't have pc, but do keep having the psa. Checked to be sure nothing changes. Gleason 6 is a very indolent form of the disease, and it has been said thst it is difficult for G6 to survive outside the prostate. Others have stated on here thst they've not heard of fatal cases of G6 prostate cancer, and from what I've looked up online, I couldn't see evidence of any fatal G6 prostate cancers.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and dropping PSA?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Spouse I do not mean to be offensive, but if the doctor was asked a straight out question ["he asked the doctor how many robotic prostatectomies he had done"], but the answer was too vague ["the doctor replied "tons of em". That was it, no specific number or estimation, just a vague "tons of em""], isn't it the dissatisfied patient's responsibility to ask for a more definitive answer? Or to switch to a different surgeon that will answer the question to the patient's satisfaction? Who's fault is it when a doctor does not give a full enough answer to satisfy the patient ... the doctor who answers with what he thinks is adequate, or the patient who is not satisfied yet does not ask a follow up question? As for a lack of notification about the possible complications from a particular surgery, have your reviewed all the forms that your Dad signed? I'm wondering if there is not something on a form that gave a generic warning about possible complications, etc, that are inherent in all surgeries. Posts.Title: considering sueing surgeon

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, hope all is well and you all had a happy new year. It has been a while since I last posted , but we are considering sueing my dad's urologist. Not because of the blood clots, but because of the hernia that developed which further set him back and has caused him to go into depression due to not being able to work. The urologist failed to mention that the incision could herniate, and as such, this was not even on our mind as dad considered his treatment options. I just wonder if failure to warn of that possibility can be considered negligence on behalf of the surgeon, and therefore something that we can pursue legal action over. I do not intend to start drama, and if this post does start drama, I sincerely apologize in advance. As we all know, outcomes of surgery rely heavily on the competence and skill of the surgeon. When dad got the news he had prostate cancer, he asked the doctor how many robotic prostatectomies he had done, and the doctor replied "tons of em". That was it, no specific number or estimation, just a vague "tons of em". In hindsight, that should have raised a red flag and perhaps we should have sought advice from another urological surgeon, or even two. I feel they should be able to at least give a ball park estimate of how many procedures they have done. 500 I think, if I read correctly on here and other websites, is the threshold for a doctor to be considered proficient in this kind of operation. The doctor who repaired the hernia(a general surgeon) said that the area did not heal properly, and that left it predisposed to herniating. And he also said he isnt a fan of the robot because of its cost, and said in many cases, it actually takes longer to do than a standard laporoscopic approach. Of course, he could have just been saying that out of bias, but even so, it gave us second thoughts. Whats done is done though, cant go back and undo the operation, but if we had to do it all over again, I think we may have avoided this surgeon and gone with a standard laparoscopic procedure. I doubt we could make a case against the company that made tne robot, as I believe it came down to an error and lackof warning on the doctor's part. He should have been a little more specific when asked how many of these things he has done. It seemed like it offended him slightly when dad asked him.

Posts.Title: PSA Moving Lower - Before Treatment

Posts.Content: Gleason 8 is aggressive, and imaging tests are warranted prior to treatment in order to check for possible spread, as gleason 8 is high risk prostate cancer. If scans are clrar, surgery can be done, also with it being gleason 8, and your psa being so high, follow up radiation may be reco.mended as well. Its a curable disease, but it dies warrant aggressive modality since it carries a hightened risk to escape the gland and begin spreading.

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hello flag, first and foremost, thank you for your service. Fortunately, as others have stated, with a clinical stage of T1c and a PSA elevated, but under 10, it's quite likely your cancer is still inside the gland and curable. With the primary grade in your Gleason score being 4, it's probably a good idea your dr has you on ADT, this will help make it more sensitive to treatment, radiation in particular if you so choose. When prostate cancer is still inside the gland, surgery is always an option, but as with any other treatment, there are side effects. And when in the prostate, radiation has as good a success rate as surgery. Again it too has side effects to take into consideration. G 7(4+3) is a bit more aggressive than G 6 or the 3+4 pattern, but it certainly isn't as dire as an 8,9, or 10. And again with your clinical stage and PSA under 10, chances are very much in your favor that it is prostate contained, and you have several venues of treatment that are all effective in treating it. Basically it's going to come down to what YOU want to do, and when dealing with cancer, having choices is certainly a good thing. Best of luck to you, and cheers to a post procedure "zero".
Posts.Title: About to make the decision

Posts.Content: In surgical pathology, a good pathologist can certainly identify these rarer prostate cancer. There are signet cell cancers, basal and squamous cell cancers, neuroendocrine cancers that can arise in the prostate. Though it is quite rare. 95% of prostate cancers are adenocarcinomas. Adeno=glandular, carcinoma= cancer.

Posts.Title: Rare forms of metastatic cancer / Low PSA production

Posts.Content: Hi Ken, sorry to hear that you too have seen a rise in your post op PSA. Hopefully your case, and my father's will both turn out to be an error in the machine or sampling, hence why they say that the PSA must be elevated on successive tests to make a diagnosis of biochemical recurrence. If I read everything correctly, you had no EPE, negative margins, and negative lymphovascular involvement. Your gleason 7 was fortunately of the less aggressive, 3+4 is much better than 4+3. Also stated were no involvement in the seminal vesicles, that too is a good thing. Not having extraprostatic extension(cancer that escaped the inside of the gland), no lymph involvement, and no seminal vesicle involvement presents a significantly lower chance of a recurrence than a case where any of that was positive. Negative margins is very big too in lessening the chances of recurrence. Let us know what happens on your next test.

Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: reading the initial report, it sounded like you were in the clear, as it stated its findings were most likely to benign prostatic hyperplasia(enlargement of the prostate), but i see that you have also reported a finding of gleason 4+3, which is unfortunate. Can you tell us more? how many cores were positive(involved by cancer), the % of each core that was positive for cancer, exactly how much was graded pattern 4? it is never a good diagnosis, b ut going on what you have posted thus far, I would imagine your cancer is not outside the prostate, has not spread either locally or distantly, no spread to lymph nodes, and as stated, there does not appear to be cancer at or penetrating the capsule, all of which are definitely good things, and favorable prognosticators. no seminal vessel involvement is also a big vheckmark in your favor as well. I think you will do quite well with your treatment, and I think your treatment will be successful in eradicating the cancer. You will likely not be a candidate for active surveillance with the pattern 4 present, and you may also be looking at a couple treatment modalities in your plan.let us know what you and your doctor discuss and figure out what you think is best in your case. always remember that when treating prostate cancer there is no such thing as a right or wrong choice.

Posts.Title: Biopsy concerns

Posts.Content: Hello flag, first and foremost, thank you for your service. Fortunately, as others have stated, with a clinical stage of T1c and a PSA elevated, but under 10, it's quite likely your cancer is still inside the gland and curable. With the primary grade in your Gleason score being 4, it's probably a good idea your dr has you on ADT, this will help make it more sensitive to treatment, radiation in particular if you so choose. When prostate cancer is still inside the gland, surgery is always an option, but as with any other treatment, there are side effects. And when in the prostate, radiation has as good a success rate as surgery. Again it too has side effects to take into consideration. G 7(4+3) is a bit more aggressive than G 6 or the 3+4 pattern, but it certainly isn't as dire as an 8,9, or 10. And again with your clinical stage and PSA under 10, chances are very much in your favor that it is prostate contained, and you have several venues of treatment that are all effective in treating it. Basically it's going to come down to what YOU want to do, and when dealing with cancer, having choices is certainly a good thing. Best of luck to you, and cheers to a post procedure "zero".

Posts.Title: About to make the decision

Posts.Content: I am so sorry to hear such a serious diagnosis. Gleason 8 and 9 are way on up there in terms of aggressiveness. As such, it is not surprising there is bone involvement and a sky high PSA level. However, advanced prostate cancers typically will respond to aggressive treatment, at least for a while. Combination therapies such as radiation and hormone therapy can significantly reduce tumor burden, and delay progression and further metastasis. Even with serious casesvlike that, men have been known to live sevdral years following their diagnosis. At this time surgery is not an option, so the first step is to meet a medical oncologist specializing in advanced prostate cancer, and a good radiation oncologist. I've heard of men with similar stats living 8+ years. While it cannot be cured, it can be controlled and managed. With prompt and aggressive treatment, your husband can live many more years, progression free and with a good quality of life. And who knows what breakthroughs may be around the corner.

Posts.Content: My dad had one on for about that long. Posts.Title: Catheter removal times?

Posts.Content: After going back, reading kther topics, informqtion about my dad's case as well, given that his was proven to be gleason 6 on surgical pathology and his PSA was "only 4.2" with it having cancer AND being enlarged, I am just about as close to 100% certain it was truely an indolent, organ limited disease as one can be. In hindsight he vrry well could have chose active surveillance instead of treating it right away, but given that the enlargement of the gland was causing him to urinate frequently, experience major urges to go, etc, I'd say the surgery was in the end, the best thing for him to do, as radiation of either modality would have onky treated the cancer, and not the enlargement, he still would have been going to the bathroom alot. And he would have continued to have urinsry frequency and urgency if he had chosen AS. So despite he experienced blood clots and wound up in sicu because of it, surgery was the best option in his case. It got the cancer out and relieved his urinary symptoms caused by the glanx enlargement. He's still on one pad a day, and unfortunztely, the doc said at this point in time that the incontinence has resolved as much as it was going to, without surgical intervention such as implanting a sling to control it. However that is a small price to pay in order to be rid of the cancer and it is worth it in our opinion. He can still have that sling procedure if he wants, but given that henis pretty much surgery weary at this point ( hernia repair the yesr before the prostatectomy, and another operagion this past January to repair an incisional hernia ghat came up at the largest prodtatectomy incision site 8 months after the prostate ordeal), and he doesn't feel its worth the blood clot risk again for an elective operation. He says all that matters now is the cancer is gone, and given that he wishes to remain single now, all other side effects such as ED are more than acceptable since it got rid of the cancer. We are both pretty much as close to as 100% sure prostate cancer will never again be an issue for him, but we are also aware of the very, very minute off chance it coulx return. So it sounds clich, but we are 99.99999999999% confident the cancer is gone and will never return.

Posts.Title: Second PSA test of the year for dad tomorrow at 10AM CDT

Posts.Content: Active surveillance is a good option for you with Gleason 6 cancer and only one core being positive, and 20% of a single core isn't much at all when you look at the prostate as a whole. You are also a good candidate for surgery a t your age and biopsy results. You being young would make for an easier and quicker recovery than it would in older men. And if the tumor is indeed confined to the gland, then yes, removal of the gland would be considered a cure. With you being rather young for a man with prostate cancer, your recovery from any incontinence issues should be quick, provided of course you do have surgery. If one had to have cancer and was able to pick what grade, you definitely got the best one. Not to be a downer, but in 20-30% of cases in surgical specimens, the Gleason score is upgraded a bit, because sometimes higher grade cancer is found than what the biopsy found. Usually a Gleason 6 that is upgraded, is upgraded to a 7, haven't really heard of many G6 cancers being upgraded to 8 or higher grades.
Posts.Title: Biopsy is positive for cancer ... now what?

Posts.Content: Results are in, and his PSA was 0.01, doctor said the cancer "was still controlled". Didn't like that phrase becausebthat makes it sound as if cancerous prostate cells are still present. And I did remember to ask him if prostate cancer, even G6 can morph into G7,8,9,10, and he said yes, it can morph into a more aggressive grade.

Posts.Title: Second PSA test of the year for dad tomorrow at 10AM CDT

Posts.Content: Gleason 6 prostate cancer is the "best" prostate cancer to have. While the gleason scale does go from 2 to 10, hardly do you ever hear of anything less than gleason 6 being found. Some people might think "6 out of a scale of10 is kind of high", but in practice today, gleason 6 is the lowest grade prostate cancer to be found. Hardly, if ever do you hear of men dying from gleason 6 disease. If they have, it is likely in those cases there was a much more aggressive, higher grade cancer present among the G6. That PSA while elevated, is not too bad, and indicates an early stage disease when combined with the gleason score. With PSA that low, and Gleason 6 disease, active surveillance is possible, depending on tne number of cores involved, unless im mistaken, to be considered for AS Gleason score should be G6, PSA under 10, and no more than two cores positive for cancer. As Highlander mentioned, AS is somewhat of a risky thing to do, even if biopsy only shows G6 in 2 cores or less, it is possible for higher grade cancers to be missed because the biopsy only takes a very small portion of tissue to be examimed. Most of the time, an astute pathologist gets it right on the biopsy. However some less practiced pathologists may underestimate the cancer, but the only way to find the true grade, stage, and extent of prostate cancer, is to have the gland removed. The pathologist can sample the entire prostate and seminal vesicles in this case, and it can confirm the biopsy assessment, and the gleason score remains the same, or in up to 20% of cases, post surgical pathology reveals more extensive, higher grade prostate cancer. In rare cases, surgical patholovy may reveal less aggressive disease, but this is the exception and not the general rule. Not uncommonly do hou hear of g6 cancers being upgraded to g7. And g7 is usually 3+4 or 4+3. A 3+4 g7 prostate cancer is less aggressive than 4+3 g7 prostate cancer. Fortunately it sounds like this cancer was detected early and there are many options for treating iit and achieving a good outcome. Radiation is quite effective on g6 disease, as is surgery, hormone therapy is not curative, it is used to slow the progress of prostate cancer, and perhaps can make radiatiom more effective. Youve mentioned hes been on AS for a few years, and you said his recent PSA was 5 and it is gleason 6 cancer. If that hasnt changed and no more than 2 cores are positive, AS can be continued. But perhaps for peace of mind, treatment wouldnt be a bad idea either. Some understandably find it hard to leave cancer in their body, and want it out asap. My dad was one of these. Even though he had 5 cores positive, 3 ocer the recommendation of 2 or less for AS, his urologist did offer him AS, and time to decide on trestment. Dad decided right then when he got his biopay results that he wanted surgery, as he didnf like thr idea of cancer being leff inside , no matter how "indolent" it may have seen. Surgery does carry risk, and you can see in my signaturr the complications my dad had as a result of his surgery. And his is one resson why I think men with g6 disease shouldnt rush into treatment, as the side effexts/ complications can be quite significant, whereas they can avoid it altogether by choosing AS and only deciding to treat it, if it shows signs of progression. You

Posts.Title: Questions to ask at upcoming Dr appt

Posts.Content: Hello there. Gleason 3+4 isnt the worst to have by any means, but unfortunately with a core having 50% involvement, that pretty much makes AS not an option. Given your heart condition, radiation therapy is a grear choice of treatment, and is pretty much as effective as surgery in treating prostate cancer. Can you guve us some mlre info? Things such as: DRE results: was it normal, or did the dr note lumps, bumps, indulation, or firmness? PSA: What was your psa level, and if it had been measured several times, what were the trends? Overall biopsy results: was that the only positive core, ir were there others? Aside from your heart condition, are there medical issues such as diabetes? Diabetes can hinder recovery from.radiatuon therapy. There are nomograms developed by sloan kettering that can give you an idea on how likely it is your disease is to br organ confined, and how likely you are to be free of disease at 5 years with radiation therapy. Your Gleason score and PSA are the most important factors in this nomogram. Note that since you are not having surgery, your PSA will not drop down to zero as you will still have a gland to produce psa, so dont worry if post treatment tests show some levels of PSA being detected. Good luck on your treatment, and let us know how it goes.

Posts.Title: New here... TAD Nervous Start Radiation this week -

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FredM I'm new here and don't know much about prostate cancer. Can you guys let me know if this is a reasonable course of action, or should I be asking more questions or doing something different? Here's my situation: 43 years old, good health, no symptoms, no history of prostate cancer in relatives, but I don't have many relatives, just my dad and two brothers, no uncles or cousins. Primary care doc found a possible nodule on right lobe of prostate during DRE as part of annual physical. Because of this he ordered a PSA and referred me to a urologist. PSA came back at 0.4 Urologist did DRE and said prostate was not enlarged but agreed with PCP that there was a hard area. He believes it's unlikely to be cancer, but wants to do a rectal biopsy, guided by ultrasound. From what I gather, they use local anesthetic on the biopsy using a needle. He gave me a script for 3 days of Levaquin 500mg starting day before biopsy and they will give me a shot with another antibiotic the day of. Also wants me to do an enema before the biopsy. This is all overwhelming to me and seems like a pretty involved procedure. Does doing a biopsy in my situation seem reasonable or is there another course of action that would be better and less invasive? Should I be asking more questions? Please give me any advice you have. Thank you. Hello there, with there being a nodule felt on the rectal exam, biopsy is definitely advised and warranted. The antibiotics are standardbprocedure to prevent infection after the biopsy. You will be under local anesthesia for the procedure, and as such, you shouldn't endure much pain, if any at all. The standardnprostate biopsy is usually 12 samples around the most comm8n areas in the prostate that cancer may develop. You may also be given something like a valium prior to the procedure to help you relax, at least thats what they did with my dad anyway. And I would suspect your doctor may have your PSA re tested prior to the biopsy. They don't like to do psa tests after the biopsy because nthe biopsy irritates the prostate slightly and can spike the PSA as a result. The next course ofmaction will depend on the results of your biopsy. Keep in mimd, the nodule may or may not be cancer, only examination of cells umder a microscope can determine whether it is or isn't cancer. If it is cancer, thw pathologist will assign a score to the cancer, called the Gleason Score. What this is, it is an evauluationof how abnormal rhe cells look under the microscope. There are two main components to the gleason score, and they are the primary pattern, and the second dary pattern. Primary pattern is the majority of the celluar make up, and the secondary is the pattern that composes thelesser amount of gleason grade. There is also sometimes a tertiaty pattern, which ia typicallyna higher grade than the mainntwo patterns, of it is indeed present. The g eason score ranges from 2-10 and is prpduced bybthe sums of the two biggest patterns. Lowest is gleason pattern 1 amd highest, and most aggressive is gleason pattern 5. So for example, if the primary pattern is 3 and the secondary pattern is 4, then you get a gleason score of 3+4=7, making it a Gleason 7 cancer. Of note is that in today's practice, gleason scores 5 and less are rarely used, as they are considered very mild, so the lowest score a man can get in terms of his camcer's aggressiveness is Gleason 6, 3+3=6. This is a very slpw growing cancer, and , ay not ever even tjreaten a man's life depending on their age. Gleason 7 is somewhat tricky, as it depemds on which os the primarybcomponent, amd which pattern is tje secondary component. The 3+4 bariant of Gleason 7 disease is less aggressive than the 4+3 variant. Gleason scores 8-10 are considered high grade, aggressive cancers, and require more extensove, and earlier treatment. Foetunqtely, gleason 6 is by far the mpst common form of tje disease, and is easily treated, amd very rarely, if at all spreads putside of the prostate. Men who have this lpw grade camcer jave likely had it for many years before it was diagnosed. Treatment tions depend on a person's age, overall health, Gleason score, PSA level, and whwther or not it is suspected to have penwtrated the proatate. Found early enough, basically all tions are available, including the tion of monitoring PSA , Digital rectal exams, and biopsies, this is called active surveillance. Men who choose active surveillance sont get treated right away, they simply monitor the status of the cancer through tje aforemwntioned, PSA tests, biopsy, and digital rectal exam. If these tests do show a change in the cancer, show it growing larger or becoming more aggreasive, then these men initiate treatment. Treatment for prostate cancer includes the following options: surgery, which os commonly performed with a robot now, instead of the traditional open, large incision operation. Radiation therapy: external beam radiation therapy, o4 brachytherapy, which is the implantayion of small, radioactive seeds placed in the prostate, these don't emit enough radiation to harm you, but do emit enough to successfully treat the cancer. Hormone therapy: this includes agents that block the reception of testosterone in prostate cancer. This is not curative, but cam be used with rafiation to male the tumor mpre susceptible to radiation.. At your ypung age, if it is determined you have prostate cancer, and it is not of a high grade, and appears contained to the prostate, surgery would likely be recommended foe you, given that in a healthy man with no signifocant existing diseases like heart disease, and life expectancy of at least 10 more years, and id say at your age, youd more than exceed that 10 year life expectancy. Of course if you do not like the idea of surgery, you can go with the other options as well. Since itnis very highly likely your life expectancy will far ezceed 10 more years, active survei lance peobably wont be offered, this is usually reserved for older men(generally 65 and older), and/or those who have existing conditions that may make treatment riskier and benefits outweighed by risks. I apologize for the humongous wall of text, and plethora of spelling and grammar errors, I just wantes to give you some advice and help answer ypur questions. Keep in mind each treatment has its risks and aide effexts, so IF you are diagnosed with cancer, be sure to look at the risk and side effects of each one and then make your decision based on what you are most comfortable with, and what you feel like offers the greatest benefits to you. Best regards.

Since itnis very highly likely your life expectancy will far ezceed 10 more years, active survei lance peobably wont be offered, this is usually reserved for older men(generally 65 and older), and/or those who have existing conditions that may make treatment riskier and benefits outweighed by risks. I apologize for the humongous wall of text, and plethora of spelling and grammar errors, I just wantes to give you some advice and help answer ypur questions. Keep in mind each treatment has its risks and aide effexts, so IF you are diagnosed with cancer, be sure to look at the risk and side effects of each one and then make your decision based on what you are most comfortable with, and what you feel like offers the greatest benefits to you. Best regards.

Posts.Title: New Here - urologist wants to do biopsy

Posts.Content: Gleason 6 prostate cancer is the "best" prostate cancer to have. While the gleason scale does go from 2 to 10, hardly do you ever hear of anything less than gleason 6 being found. Some people might think "6 out of a scale of10 is kind of high", but in practice today, gleason 6 is the lowest grade prostate cancer to be found. Hardly, if ever do you hear of men dying from gleason 6 disease. If they have, it is likely in those cases there was a much more aggressive, higher grade cancer present among the G6. That PSA while elevated, is not too bad, and indicates an early stage disease when combined with the gleason score. With PSA that low, and Gleason 6 disease, active surveillance is possible, depending on tne number of cores involved, unless im mistaken, to be considered for AS Gleason score should be G6, PSA under 10, and no more than two cores positive for cancer. As Highlander mentioned, AS is somewhat of a risky thing to do, even if biopsy only shows G6 in 2 cores or less, it is possible for higher grade cancers to be missed because the biopsy only takes a very small portion of tissue to be examimed. Most of the time, an astute pathologist gets it right on the biopsy. However some less practiced pathologists may underestimate the cancer, but the only way to find the true grade, stage, and extent of prostate cancer, is to have the gland removed. The pathologist can sample the entire prostate and seminal vesicles in this case, and it can confirm the biopsy assessment, and the gleason score remains the same, or in up to 20% of cases, post surgical pathology reveals more extensive, higher grade prostate cancer. In rare cases, surgical patholovy may reveal less aggressive disease, but this is the exception and not the general rule. Not uncommonly do hou hear of g6 cancers being upgraded to g7. And g7 is usually 3+4 or 4+3. A 3+4 g7 prostate cancer is less aggressive than 4+3 g7 prostate cancer. Fortunately it sounds like this cancer was detected early and there are many options for treating iit and achieving a good outcome. Radiation is quite effective on g6 disease, as is surgery, hormone therapy is not curative, it is used to slow the progress of prostate cancer, and perhaps can make radiatiom more effective. Youve mentioned hes been on AS for a few years, and you said his recent PSA was 5 and it is gleason 6 cancer. If that hasnt changed and no more than 2 cores are positive, AS can be continued. But perhaps for peace of mind, treatment wouldnt be a bad idea either. Some understandably find it hard to leave cancer in their body, and want it out asap. My dad was one of these. Even though he had 5 cores positive, 3 ocer the recommendation of 2 or less for AS, his urologist did offer him AS, and time to decide on trestment. Dad decided right then when he got his biopay results that he wanted surgery, as he didnf like thr idea of cancer being leff inside , no matter how "indolent" it may have seen. Surgery does carry risk, and you can see in my signaturr the complications my dad had as a result of his surgery. And his is one resson why I think men with g6 disease shouldnt rush into treatment, as the side effexts/ complications can be quite significant, whereas they can avoid it altogether by choosing AS and only deciding to treat it, if it shows signs of progression. You

Posts.Title: Questions to ask at upcoming Dr appt

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FredM I'm new here and don't know much about prostate cancer. Can you guys let me know if this is a reasonable course of action, or should I be asking more questions or doing something different? Here's my situation: 43 years old, good health, no symptoms, no history of prostate cancer in relatives, but I don't have many relatives, just my dad and two brothers, no uncles or cousins. Primary care doc found a possible nodule on right lobe of prostate during DRE as part of annual physical. Because of this he ordered a PSA and referred me to a urologist. PSA came back at 0.4 Urologist did DRE and said prostate was not enlarged but agreed with PCP that there was a hard area. He believes it's unlikely to be cancer, but wants to do a rectal biopsy, guided by ultrasound. From what I gather, they use local anesthetic on the biopsy using a needle. He gave me a script for 3 days of Levaquin 500mg starting day before biopsy and they will give me a shot with another antibiotic the day of. Also wants me to do an enema before the biopsy. This is all overwhelming to me and seems like a pretty involved procedure. Does doing a biopsy in my situation seem reasonable or is there another course of action that would be better and less invasive? Should I be asking more questions? Please give me any advice you have. Thank you. Hello there, with there being a nodule felt on the rectal exam, biopsy is definitely advised and warranted. The antibiotics are standardbprocedure to prevent infection after the biopsy. You will be under local anesthesia for the procedure, and as such, you shouldn't endure much pain, if any at all. The standardnprostate biopsy is usually 12 samples around the most comm8n areas in the prostate that cancer may develop. You may also be given something like a valium prior to the procedure to help you relax, at least thats what they did with my dad anyway. And I would suspect your doctor may have your PSA re tested prior to the biopsy. They don't like to do psa tests after the biopsy because nthe biopsy irritates the prostate slightly and can spike the PSA as a result. The next course ofmaction will depend on the results of your biopsy. Keep in mimd, the nodule may or may not be cancer, only examination of cells umder a microscope can determine whether it is or isn't cancer. If it is cancer, thw pathologist will assign a score to the cancer, called the Gleason Score. What this is, it is an evauluationof how abnormal rhe cells look under the microscope. There are two main components to the gleason score, and they are the primary pattern, and the second dary pattern. Primary pattern is the majority of the celluar make up, and the secondary is the pattern that composes thelesser amount of gleason grade. There is also sometimes a tertiaty pattern, which ia typicallyna higher grade than the mainntwo patterns, of it is indeed present. The g eason score ranges from 2-10 and is prpduced bybthe sums of the two biggest patterns. Lowest is gleason pattern 1 amd highest, and most aggressive is gleason pattern 5. So for example, if the primary pattern is 3 and the secondary pattern is 4, then you get a gleason score of 3+4=7, making it a Gleason 7 cancer. Of note is that in today's practice, gleason scores 5 and less are rarely used, as they are considered very mild, so the lowest score a man can get in terms of his camcer's aggressiveness is Gleason 6, 3+3=6. This is a very slpw growing cancer, and , ay not ever even tjreaten a man's life depending on their age. Gleason 7 is somewhat tricky, as it depemds on which os the primarybcomponent, amd which pattern is tje secondary component. The 3+4 bariant of Gleason 7 disease is less aggressive than the 4+3 variant. Gleason scores 8-10 are considered high grade, aggressive cancers, and require more extensove, and earlier treatment. Foetunqtely, gleason 6 is by far the mpst common form of tje disease, and is easily treated, amd very rarely, if at all spreads putside of the prostate. Men who have this lpw grade camcer jave likely had it for many years before it was diagnosed. Treatment tions depend on a person's age, overall health, Gleason score, PSA level, and whwther or not it is suspected to have penwtrated the proatate. Found early enough, basically all tions are available, including the tion of monitoring PSA , Digital rectal exams, and biopsies, this is called active surveillance. Men who choose active surveillance sont get treated right away, they simply monitor the status of the cancer through tje aforemwntioned, PSA tests, biopsy, and digital rectal exam. If these tests do show a change in the cancer, show it growing larger or becoming more aggreasive, then these men initiate treatment. Treatment for prostate cancer includes the following options: surgery, which os commonly performed with a robot now, instead of the traditional open, large incision operation. Radiation therapy: external beam radiation therapy, o4 brachytherapy, which is the implantayion of small, radioactive seeds placed in the prostate, these don't emit enough radiation to harm you, but do emit enough to successfully treat the cancer. Hormone therapy: this includes agents that block the reception of testosterone in prostate cancer. This is not curative, but cam be used with rafiation to male the tumor mpre susceptible to radiation.. At your ypung age, if it is determined you have prostate cancer, and it is not of a high grade, and appears contained to the prostate, surgery would likely be recommended foe you, given that in a healthy man with no signifocant existing diseases like heart disease, and life expectancy of at least 10 more years, and id say at your age, youd more than exceed that 10 year life expectancy. Of course if you do not like the idea of surgery, you can go with the other options as well. Since itnis very highly likely your life expectancy will far ezceed 10 more years, active survei lance peobably wont be offered, this is usually reserved for older men(generally 65 and older), and/or those who have existing conditions that may make treatment riskier and benefits outweighed by risks. I apologize for the humongous wall of text, and plethora of spelling and grammar errors, I just wantes to give you some advice and help answer ypur questions. Keep in mind each treatment has its risks and aide effexts, so IF you are diagnosed with cancer, be sure to look at the risk and side effects of each one and then make your decision based on what you are most comfortable with, and what you feel like offers the greatest benefits to you. Best regards.

Posts.Content: Also, biopsy results should be available 7-10 days after the biopsy is done. You will then have an appointment to discuss the results, and if positive for cancer, you and your doctor will go over treatment options. The low PSA of 0.4 is certainly good, however, the nodule does raise suspicion and thus is why you are getting a biopsy. It is poasible to jave prostate cancer, even though PSA levels may be low, and higher readings can result from benign causes on the flip side.

Posts.Title: New Here - urologist wants to do biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Ken, sorry to hear that you too have seen a rise in your post op PSA. Hopefully your case, and my father's will both turn out to be an error in the machine or sampling, hence why they say that the PSA must be elevated on successive tests to make a diagnosis of biochemical recurrence. If I read everything correctly, you had no EPE, negative margins, and negative lymphovascular involvement. Your gleason 7 was fortunately of the less aggressive, 3+4 is much better than 4+3. Also stated were no involvement in the seminal vesicles, that too is a good thing. Not having extraprostatic extension(cancer that escaped the inside of the gland), no lymph involvement, and no seminal vesicle involvement presents a significantly lower chance of a recurrence than a case where any of that was positive. Negative margins is very big too in lessening the chances of recurrence. Let us know what happens on your next test.

Posts.Content: Gleason 8 is aggressive, and imaging tests are warranted prior to treatment in order to check for possible spread, as gleason 8 is high risk prostate cancer. If scans are clrar, surgery can be done, also with it being gleason 8, and your psa being so high, follow up radiation may be reco.mended as well. Its a curable disease, but it dies warrant aggressive modality since it carries a hightened risk to escape the gland and begin spreading.

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi there, hate to hear that you have prostate cancer. Acvording to your biopsy, you fortunately have the least aggressive firm of it. Gleason 6 as Highlander said, virtually doesn't kill anyone. Active surveillance could have been an option pwrhaps, but they usually recommend that for cases with 3 or less positive cores. Which leads us to youre current dilema: how to treat this cancer. As you know, there is no universal be all, end all treatment for prostate cancer patients. Each case, while similar in many ways to other men, is unique in its own way. Some guys a are much younger than the average age of diagnosis (roughly 65), and you at 44 fall into this category. Others may be of advanced age, say over 75 where treatment might not be recommended treatment due to life expectancy. Also, some men may have significant exidting conditions that may disuade againsr certain treatments. For those who do have treatment, there are many cancer specific factors thst you can use to decide ahat is best for YOU, based on your preferences, and desires to avoid side effects and risks of a certain treatment modality. At 44 years old, and with your low gleason score, im pretty sure your dr has recommended surgery, as they are naturally biased toward their specialty. But you also got to take into account your preferences, what you wish to do, and what you think gives you the bedt chsnce of successful trestment while minimalizing side effects and complications. Surgery and radiation therspy have similar success rates in treating organ confined disease. Surgery runs the risk of infection, stroke, heart attack, blood clots (my dad duffered these). Radistion side effects are generally more delayed and has its own unique side effe ts and complications. And the cyberknife radiation slunds promiding, as it is supposed to target specifically the tumor area (or areas. Prostate cancer is often multifocal), and spare healthy tissue from the ill effects of radiation. You mention that you have spoken with a surgeon who hasdone thousands of open prostatectomies as you said. Experience is VERY important in choosing a physician to treat you, no matter what modality you go with. This surgeon having done thousands of them epuld be thd kind of surgeon to go to if you do choose surgery. Hes well past the learning curve, and at having done so many of them, hes very proficient at it. A surgeon like that invreases suvcess rstes dramatically, and preservation of continence and sexual function kd much greater with a well versed surheon like that, than it would be from one who's only done a couple hundred. With Gleason 6, time is on your side, youve got plenty of time to make a decision. Assess the pros and cons of each treatment modality, and choose one that you feel best suits your goals, and kffers you the least risk of unwanted side effects. Let us know when you decide, we will be here with you every step of the way. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Struggling with course of treatment decision?

Posts.Content: Hi there, hate to hear that you have prostate cancer. Acvording to your biopsy, you fortunately have the least aggressive firm of it. Gleason 6 as Highlander said, virtually doesn't kill anyone. Active surveillance could have been an option pwrhaps, but they usually recommend that for cases with 3 or less positive cores. Which leads us to youre current dilema: how to treat this cancer. As you know, there is no universal be all, end all treatment for prostate cancer patients. Each case, while similar in many ways to other men, is unique in its own way. Some guys a are much younger than the average age of diagnosis (roughly 65), and you at 44 fall into this category. Others may be of advanced age, say over 75 where treatment might not be recommended treatment due to life expectancy. Also, some men may have significant exidting conditions that may disuade againsr certain treatments. For those who do have treatment, there are many cancer specific factors thst you can use to decide ahat is best for YOU, based on your preferences, and desires to avoid side effects and risks of a certain treatment modality. At 44 years old, and with your low gleason score, im pretty sure your dr has recommended surgery, as they are naturally biased toward their specialty. But you also got to take into account your preferences, what you wish to do, and what you think gives you the bedt chsnce of successful trestment while minimalizing side effects and complications. Surgery and radiation therspy have similar success rates in treating organ confined disease. Surgery runs the risk of infection, stroke, heart attack, blood clots (my dad duffered these). Radistion side effects are generally more delayed and has its own unique side effe ts and complications. And the cyberknife radiation slunds promiding, as it is supposed to target specifically the tumor area (or areas. Prostate cancer is often multifocal), and spare healthy tissue from the ill effects of radiation. You mention that you have spoken with a surgeon who hasdone thousands of open prostatectomies as you said. Experience is VERY important in choosing a physician to treat you, no matter what modality you go with. This surgeon having done thousands of them epuld be thd kind of surgeon to go to if you do choose surgery. Hes well past the learning curve, and at having done so many of them, hes very proficient at it. A surgeon like that invreases suvcess rstes dramatically, and preservation of continence and sexual function kd much greater with a well versed surheon like that, than it would be from one who's only done a couple hundred. With Gleason 6, time is on your side, youve got plenty of time to make a decision. Assess the pros and cons of each treatment modality, and choose one that you feel best suits your goals, and kffers you the least risk of unwanted side effects. Let us know when you decide, we will be here with you every step of the way. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Struggling with course of treatment decision?

Posts.Content: Heal as much as you can and get ready for the radiation. It was a high grade, aggressive prostate cancer, so having the operation done now was definitely prudent. Glad you got a doctor that is staying on top of the ball. With such a high Gleason score, I'm wondering if they will order imaging studies and bone scans-- normal protocol for high Gleason score cancers. The fact there was some margin involvement is not surprising, given the Gleason score, but at least there was no SVI and no angiolymphatic involvement, that's a favorable prognosticators. Radiation as soon as you are healed enough to tolerate It is a must. Sooner you can initiate that, the better off you'll be. I think you probably got to it in time going by the clear CT and bone scans, and no evidence of node involvement. Had you waited around, it might have been considerably worse.

Posts.Title: Got my Path final report back, not good

Posts.Content: As many of you know, my dad suffered bilateral DVT and bilateral massive PE. This was a risk of any surgery, and in gwnwral, the longer your under sedation, the higher your risk. Noone IA to blame as it is just an inherent risk of surgwry. Was 63 at the time now 65, for a long time he couldn't so a lot of stuff he used roo because of the damage done by the PEs. Now however, hes at least 95% back to where he was prior to the operation. He's gained a lot of strength and endurance back over the last several months. He got his CDL license reinstated and is intending on at leat coming partially out of retiremwmt, and is job hunting now. He is also back to doing yard work and even trimming and cutting bushes, which can be quite taxing at times. It is great to see this, it was hard watching him being down and out and not really himself. We had gotten worried the PEs had done extensive permanent damage. But after reading stories of other pe zurvivors, it takes a lot of time to fully recover from such a devastating medical crisis. He can be quite ornery at times, but I am so very thankful he's here and is doing a lot better. I'd rather see him ornery than a she'll of his formerself. PSA continues to be zero, or undetectable 2+ years post op, so things look great in regards to the PCA too. He has another psa test in december, and while we are quite aware a recurrence is possible, we don't dwell on that. We believe and continue to expect more zeros in the future. He's now on two x per year tests instead of theach every 3-4 months that he was 8nitially, so the surgeon is quite happy as well. Looking forward to more zeroes, and they said since the PEs were provoked (ie resulting from surgery or trauma) they don't really forsee a recurrence of the blood clots.

Posts.Title: Got my Path final report back, not good

Posts.Content: Hi Ken, sorry to hear that you too have seen a rise in your post op PSA. Hopefully your case, and my father's will both turn out to be an error in the machine or sampling, hence why they say that the PSA must be elevated on successive tests to make a diagnosis of biochemical recurrence. If I read everything correctly, you had no EPE, negative margins, and negative lymphovascular involvement. Your gleason 7 was fortunately of the less aggressive, 3+4 is much better than 4+3. Also stated were no involvement in the seminal vesicles, that too is a good thing. Not having extraprostatic extension(cancer that escaped the inside of the gland), no lymph involvement, and no seminal vesicle involvement presents a significantly lower chance of a recurrence than a case where any of that was positive. Negative margins is very big too in lessening the chances of recurrence. Let us know what happens on your next test.

Posts.Title: I'm back, with less than great news

Posts.Content: Hello there, sorry to hear your husband has been diagnoSed with prostate cancer. At this point, anti biotics might bring the PSA down a bit if there is infection present in the prostate, but it will have no affect on the cancer like highlander said. Your signature shows he was diagnosed with Gleason 6 cancer and no lumps, bumps, or firmness was not found on the DRE, this is good. However, the PSA increasing in that amount of time and reaching what it is, is concerning. A PSA over 10 could perhaps be suggestive of higher grade, more aggressive cancer that the biopsy may have missed. A prostate biopsy only samples a very tiny potion of tissue and commonly(up to 30-40% of cases) misses higher grade disease. It might be suggested to get a second biopsy some. A saturation biopsy where much more than the typical 12 core biopsy is taken. This could find hidden disease the standard biopsy missed. If evidence continues to indicate it is organ confined, surgery would be the best course of treatment. With this, you would know the true nature of the disease, whereas with radiation, you are going on the biopsy report, which as mwntioned, can be uncertain. With that PSA level, it would be a good idea to get on it sooner than later, before that treatment/cure window may close. Best wishes to you and your husband.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mom2two my dad had his bone scan last week Thursday and we haven't heard anything yet. Dr. said he would not call us for negative results only if something showed up.....he does have a follow-up on the 15th of september but it's so hard to wait. Tech told us the result would get back to the dr in about 3 business days so sometime this week....I've never wanted the phone to not ring so badly.....I keep telling myself that if the CT scan was negative the odds are the bone scan will be too.....sorry to keep hashing out the same concerns....but I feel safe posting here becaue I know I'll get good advice and that you all really understand.... Definitely understand your concern there, I too would tend to think that the more imaging modalities turning up negative, the less likely it would be for something to turn up afterward. The CT cant see prostate cancer inside the prostate, according to my dad's surgeon, but it can perhaps find suspicious areas outside of the gland. And if so further imaging studies such as a bone scan can be more specific. But I believe youll be fine, even though you do have a rather high gleason score, the cancer can still be eradicated. The no evidence of extracapsular extension is favorable for you as well as the lack of seminal vesicle involvement and no evidence of lymph node involvement, these all points towards a cancer, that while is qn aggressive form, it is still confined to the prostate.

Posts.Title: Just feel comfort in posting here

Posts.Content: Sometimes these high grade, aggressive prostate cancers won't necessarily express astoundingly high PSA. In fact, I've heard of some cases of G9 and G10 prostate cancers not elevating the PSA out of the normal range. I would agree with your doctor given the Gleason score and node and SV involvement that there is likely some microscopic disease still within the pelvis area. Good to see it's not showing any signs of blatant metastasis on scans though. Firmagon followed up by salvage RT is a prudent course of action in these high risk cancers like that. Hopefully that treatment regimen will knock your PSA all the way to 0 and finish the cancer off.

Posts.Title: Newby here

Posts.Content: PSA of 28 is conderning, particularly with a normal sized gland. Your previous biopsies as you mentioned, have yet to find anything. Your DRE was normal, which is certainly good, at least it isntnblatantly obvious cancer qccording to that. But with a PSA that high, one must be suspicious, even with the previous biopsies turning up negative. The saturation biopsy should be able to find cancer, if it is indeed present. It will sample portions of the proatate that are typically not checked with a standard 12 core biopsy. If you do turn out to have cancer, you may be looking at a two pronged treatment since that psa is so high. If it appears to be within the prostate, you could have surgery(if you so choose), and since the PSA is so high, radiation may be recommended afterward to eliminate any possible stragglers left behind. Or perhaps you could have hormone therapy combined with radiation therapy, hormone therapy in this instance would be used to make the cancer more sensitive to radiation, therefore jncreasing the liklihood of success. Of course all of this depends on your preferences, your overall state of health, gleason grade, and if the saturation biopsy even finds cancer. But with that PSA so high on a normal size glad, I'd be rather suspicious there may be cancer lurking in there. Until you reach that road(again, if cancer is even found), do your homework, research prostate cancer and the side effects of it and its treatments, arm yourself with as much knowledge as possible and go from there. And above all, this still isn't a time for panic, as cancer producing that high of psa, again provided it is found in your prostate, it can still be cured and you can still enjoy many years of good health.

Posts.Title: Second PSA test of the year for dad tomorrow at 10AM CDT

Posts.Content: Hate to hear that you have some G8 disease, or any for that matter. With you having some G8 cancer, I would suspect the doctor will probably order bone scans and biopsy some of the nearby lymphnodes to check for possible spread to bones and nearby lymph nodes. Then those results will help guide you as to what treatment(s) you can get. If it is all within the prostate, you can have surgery to rempve the prostate, followed by radiation or hormone therapy, dependjng on you and your doctor's preferences. If it has started to break through the prostate gland, surgery might still be possible so long as it does not invade nearby tissues and structures such as then seminal vesicles. If it is invading nearby structures and possibly into local lymph nodes, you would not be a candidate for surgery, and thus radiation wojld be recommended, along with perhaps hormone therapy during and/or after radiation. Main thing is to get to it before it starts spreading, especially to distant parts of the body. Chemotherapy is generally only used for incurable disease and palliative purposes only. Hope you have a good report and get started on tackling this thing.

Posts.Title: Gleason score 7's & 8's

Posts.Content: I am so sorry to hear such a serious diagnosis. Gleason 8 and 9 are way on up there in terms of aggressiveness. As such, it is not surprising there is bone involvement and a sky high PSA level. However, advanced prostate cancers typically will respond to aggressive treatment, at least for a while. Combination therapies such as radiation and hormone therapy can significantly reduce tumor burden, and delay progression and further metastasis. Even with serious casesvlike that, men have been known to live sevdral years following their diagnosis. At this time surgery is not an option, so the first step is to meet a medical oncologist specializing in advanced prostate cancer, and a good radiation oncologist. I've heard of men with similar stats living 8+ years. While it cannot be cured, it can be controlled and managed. With prompt and aggressive treatment, your husband can live many more years, progression free and with a good quality of life. And who knows what breakthroughs may be around the corner.

Posts.Content: I wouldn't say that was too long. Most men have had their prostate cancer for several years before they are diagnosed anyway, and fortunately, most are diagnosed with a lower grade disease such as gleason 6, even the 3+4 variant of gleason 7 isnt terrible, it is still likely in that case the cancer had been there for several years, and most likely didn't grow much, if at all in that time frame. Based on the info your signature provides, I agree with the previous post, you are still in good shape in regards to the cancer.

Posts.Title: prostate biopsy due to sudden elevated PSA

Posts.Content: Active surveillance is a good option for you with Gleason 6 cancer and only one core being positive, and 20% of a single core isn't much at all when you look at the prostate as a whole. You are also a good candidate for surgery a t your age and biopsy results. You being young would make for an easier and quicker recovery than it would in older men. And if the tumor is indeed confined to the gland, then yes, removal of the gland would be considered a cure. With you being rather young for a man with prostate cancer, your recovery from any incontinence issues should be quick, provided of course you do have surgery. If one had to have cancer and was able to pick what grade, you definitely got the best one. Not to be a downer, but in 20-30% of cases in surgical specimens, the Gleason score is upgraded a bit, because sometimes higher grade cancer is found than what the biopsy found. Usually a Gleason 6 that is upgraded, is upgraded to a 7, haven't really heard of many G6 cancers being upgraded to 8 or higher grades.

Posts.Title: New Here - urologist wants to do biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FredM I'm new here and don't know much about prostate cancer. Can you guys let me know if this is a reasonable course of action, or should I be asking more questions or doing something different? Here's my situation: 43 years old, good health, no symptoms, no history of prostate cancer in relatives, but I don't have many relatives, just my dad and two brothers, no uncles or cousins. Primary care doc found a possible nodule on right lobe of prostate during DRE as part of annual physical. Because of this he ordered a PSA and referred me to a urologist. PSA came back at 0.4 Urologist did DRE and said prostate was not enlarged but agreed with PCP that there was a hard area. He believes it's unlikely to be cancer, but wants to do a rectal biopsy, guided by ultrasound. From what I gather, they use local anesthetic on the biopsy using a needle. He gave me a script for 3 days of Levaquin 500mg starting day before biopsy and they will give me a shot with another antibiotic the day of. Also wants me to do an enema before the biopsy. This is all overwhelming to me and seems like a pretty involved procedure. Does doing a biopsy in my situation seem reasonable or is there another course of action that would be better and less invasive? Should I be asking more questions? Please give me any advice you have. Thank you. Hello there, with there being a nodule felt on the rectal exam, biopsy is definitely advised and warranted. The antibiotics are standardbprocedure to prevent infection after the biopsy. You will be under local anesthesia for the procedure, and as such, you shouldn't endure much pain, if any at all. The standardnprostate biopsy is usually 12 samples around the most comm8n areas in the prostate that cancer may develop. You may also be given something like a valium prior to the procedure to help you relax, at least thats what they did with my dad anyway. And I would suspect your doctor may have your PSA re tested prior to the biopsy. They don't like to do psa tests after the biopsy because nthe biopsy irritates the prostate slightly and can spike the PSA as a result. The next course ofmaction will depend on the results of your biopsy. Keep in mimd, the nodule may or may not be cancer, only examination of cells umder a microscope can determine whether it is or isn't cancer. If it is cancer, thw pathologist will assign a score to the cancer, called the Gleason Score. What this is, it is an evauluationof how abnormal rhe cells look under the microscope. There are two main components to the gleason score, and they are the primary pattern, and the second dary pattern. Primary pattern is the majority of the celluar make up, and the secondary is the pattern that composes thelesser amount of gleason grade. There is also sometimes a tertiaty pattern, which ia typicallyna higher grade than the mainntwo patterns, of it is indeed present. The g eason score ranges from 2-10 and is prpduced bybthe sums of the two biggest patterns. Lowest is gleason pattern 1 amd highest, and most aggressive is gleason pattern 5. So for example, if the primary pattern is 3 and the secondary pattern is 4, then you get a gleason score of 3+4=7, making it a Gleason 7 cancer. Of note is that in today's practice, gleason scores 5 and less are rarely used, as they are considered very mild, so the lowest score a man can get in terms of his camcer's aggressiveness is Gleason 6, 3+3=6. This is a very slpw growing cancer, and , ay not ever even tjreaten a man's life depending on their age. Gleason 7 is somewhat tricky, as it depemds on which os the primarybcomponent, amd which pattern is tje secondary component. The 3+4 bariant of Gleason 7 disease is less aggressive than the 4+3 variant. Gleason scores 8-10 are considered high grade, aggressive cancers, and require more extensove, and earlier treatment. Foetunqtely, gleason 6 is by far the mpst common form of tje disease, and is easily treated, amd very rarely, if at all spreads putside of the prostate. Men who have this lpw grade camcer jave likely had it for many years before it was diagnosed. Treatment tions depend on a person's age, overall health, Gleason score, PSA level, and whwther or not it is suspected to have penwtrated the proatate. Found early enough, basically all tions are available, including the tion of monitoring PSA , Digital rectal exams, and biopsies, this is called active surveillance. Men who choose active surveillance sont get treated right away, they simply monitor the status of the cancer through tje aforemwntioned, PSA tests, biopsy, and digital rectal exam. If these tests do show a change in the cancer, show it growing larger or becoming more aggreasive, then these men initiate treatment. Treatment for prostate cancer includes the following options: surgery, which os commonly performed with a robot now, instead of the traditional open, large incision operation. Radiation therapy: external beam radiation therapy, o4 brachytherapy, which is the implantayion of small, radioactive seeds placed in the prostate, these don't emit enough radiation to harm you, but do emit enough to successfully treat the cancer. Hormone therapy: this includes agents that block the reception of testosterone in prostate cancer. This is not curative, but cam be used with rafiation to male the tumor mpre susceptible to radiation.. At your ypung age, if it is determined you have prostate cancer, and it is not of a high grade, and appears contained to the prostate, surgery would likely be recommended foe you, given that in a healthy man with no signifocant existing diseases like heart disease, and life expectancy of at least 10 more years, and id say at your age, youd more than exceed that 10 year life expectancy. Of course if you do not like the idea of surgery, you can go with the other options as well. Since itnis very highly likely your life expectancy will far ezceed 10 more years, active survei lance peobably wont be offered, this is usually reserved for older men(generally 65 and older), and/or those who have existing conditions that may make treatment riskier and benefits outweighed by risks. I apologize for the humongous wall of text, and plethora of spelling and grammar errors, I just wantes to give you some advice and help answer ypur questions. Keep in mind each treatment has its risks and aide effexts, so IF you are diagnosed with cancer, be sure to look at the risk and side effects of each one and then make your decision based on what you are most comfortable with, and what you feel like offers the greatest benefits to you. Best regards.

Posts.Title: New Here - urologist wants to do biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mikesimm I spoke with my RO, Dr. Shah, today. His reply to my note (see above) is that he is ok with waiting until my PSA ticks up to 0.03 to start RT treatments, whether that is 6 months from now or 6 years. He says it's the PSA that matters, not the elapsed time since surgery. He also said there is a "few percentage points" side effects advantage to Proton therapy treatment as opposed to IMRT due to less "scattering", but he is ok with either. So for now, I will get another PSA about Sept. 1, and every three months thereafter for a while, and if it goes to 0.03, I'll be getting zapped pronto, most likely on Proton as every little advantage helps! Mike in Kerrville Excellent idea to be ready to tackle it when/if the PSA should reach 0.03 again. I believe in that case getting it done then would be most beneficial to you, and would quite likely be a successful treatment result. I certainly like it better than waiting til say like 0.2 like many physicans like to do. And of course if it does not reach that 0.03 threshold, then no action would be neccessary at the time, and you would get to avoid those side effects. I agree with the doctor that PSA is more important than time that has passed by since surgery. PSA is far more of accurate assessment of what prostate cancer does, and if it has returned after treatment. Hopefully it wont reach 0.03 and you wont have to begin therapy for it, but if it does come to that, I think you would do well.

Posts.Content: My dad had one on for about that long. Reason being was because when they go to remove catheters, theyll test to make sure its healing and not leaking around the new anastmatosis (new coonnection from urethra to bladder), unfortunately his was still leaking, so he had to keep his in for an additional 2 weeks until the last scan showed no more leaking. They have a term fir that kind of leakage, but i can't remember what it is.

Posts.Title: Post op pathology back today...

Posts.Content: Perfectly normal, not paranoia in the least. The prospect of cancer is not fun, and the degree of uncertainty following treatment will make you anxious, think more about it, etc, a perfectly normal response. But thus far all your post op test have came back as either "zero" or undetectable, right? That's a great thing. The more time passes in which your PSA is zero, the less and less do you have to worry about it. My dad had his prostate removed 3 years ago, and the first few months, he too thought about his PSA and what ifs frequently. After about 6 months he started thinking less and less of it, and after a year, he got to where he hardly thought of it at all. Now it is 3 years post op, his PSA remains zero. The only time he now mentions it is a day or two before the next test, other than that, it's always on the back burner for him(though certainly not OUTRIGHT forgotten). Your thoughts about your PSA and the cancer will ebb as well, as time goes along. From what I've seen, it appears they got it while still in the gland, and that is pretty much always a positive prognosticator.

Posts.Title: Update and Final Pathology

Posts.Content: Perineural invasion is a very common finding in post surgery pathology samples. It really does not precede a negative prognosis. Pretty much every respected prostate that had cancer in it he perineural invasion. It is when perineural invasion is significant enough to be found on biopsy that bit perhaps may be of more significance. But given your overall report and that you got the "lesser of the two evils" when it comes to Gleason 7, in your case, 3+4, with you having such a good pathology report, I think you should be in good shape. 3+4=7 behaves more like a Gleason 6 and a 4+3 behaves more akin to Gleason 8. All in all I would say you stand a pretty ez ellent shot of having a post o.o PSA at undetectable levels, which would indicate successful treatment, and if say you have a great shot at remaining at undetectable levels.

Posts.Content: Considering they still kept it as a pT2c even with the 2 mm margin involvement at the bladder neck, it sounds like they believe no additional treatment will be needed. And from what I've cone to understand, it's not uncommon to have very small foci of cancer at the bladder neck following prostatectomy. If all is true about Gleason 3, then that 2mm should not cause problems on the future. If it had been pattern 4 at the positive margin, it may have been a different story. Key will be the post op psa in a few weeks, that should tell the tale. But from what I see, I think he will be just fine. He tolerated the surgery well, and was up and about rather quickly and able to walk the halls not long at all after the surgery. Very good sign. Be sure to tell us that post op psa here on a few weeks

Posts.Title: Hello everyone. My dad had/has prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hi, take a deep breath, you are getting a bit ahead of yourself. A 2.8 increase in one year on your PSA is certainly warranting of investigation and work up by a urologist, but by no means is it an indicator of "Fatal prostate cancer". There are other things that can cause a spike in PSA like that, prostate enlargement(BPH), and inflammation(prostatitis) of the gland can do that, especially inflammation. And of course, prostate cancer should always be considered a possibility, but there should not be any conclusions drawn. Good rule of thumb that I have seen doctors use is that "You don't have cancer until you are formally diagnosed". While there may be some fallicies with that line of thinking, it is a good thing to take into consideration with prostate cancer, and it can help curb unneccessary worrying and anxiety. IF, and that is a BIG if-- your doctor suspects the possibility of prostate cancer, he or she may recommend a repeat biopsy just for confirmation, and if that too reads elevated, then he or she will likely decide to do further work up, such as a DRE and a biopsy. If they decide on doing a DRE, keep in mind that it needs to be done AFTER any PSA test, as that can cause a false high reading, a DRE stimulates the prostate, and causes it to secrete more PSA into the blood stream. And then if based on the PSA and DRE, your doctor can determine your need for a biopsy, most of which are the standard 12 core biopsies, where they take 12 samples from various areas of the prostate, then they send those samples to pathology for determination of if there is malignancy present or not. A biopsy is the way to go in determining whether or not someone has prostate cancer, as it gives you a more direct look at the behavior of the cells in the gland-- a PSA test cant differentiate between cancer, and prostate enlargement or prostatitis. The biopsy is generally pretty safe with no complications, though some people have had a rough time with it. One of the complications that comes from a prostate biopsy is an infection, but this is relatively uncommon now, as the ordering physician will give you some anti biotics to take before and after the biopsy in order to cut down the risk of an infection following the procedure. With a standard prostate biopsy, you will be given a local anasthetic, you wont be put to sleep unless you request to, and they will likely prescribe you one or two anti anxiety pills to take prior in order to help you relax. It doesn't hurt, you might feel a bit of pressure and you might feel a tug when the doctor pulls the samples out, but it really is not a painful procedure. After that is done, go home and relax, and when you are ready, go back to doing your usual activities and await the appointment to discuss the results of the biopsy, which should be about a week afterward, 10 days at most. And at that time, you can decide what to do if anything needs to be done, based off the results.
