Posts.Title: Update and Final Pathology

Posts.Content: Hello, my name is Brandon and my father was diagnosed with prostate cancer this year after a blood test on January 25 revealed his PSA was 4.2 . He was then referred to a urologist whom did a DRE and then a biopsy on March 8th after that. Results were discussed March 19th, and the doctor said unfortunately the biopsy revealed 5 out of 12 cores positive for cancer. Gleason grade was 3+3 for a gleason score of 6, and based on these findings and normal DRE, the urologist said this was clinical stage 1 PCa. He gave dad several options in which to approach this cancer: Surgery, external beam radiation, brachytherapy, hormone therapy, and active surveillance. Dad asked what the doctor thought offered the best chance of long term survival, and the doctor said surgery offered the best chance. So dad decided for that, even though the doc said he could take a couple weeks to decide. Surgery was done April 23 and afterward the doc came out and said it appeared he got all the cancer and there was no kbvious signs of cancer outside of the prostate. He stayed overnight and went home early the following afternoon. He had a MAJOR, life threatening complication 15 days later that I will elaborate on at a later time. Got the surgical pathology report back and it has something in it that I dont like. I will provide the main details here. Clinical history: malignant neoplasm of prostate Microscopic diagnosis: Prostate, radical robotic prostatectomy; adenocarcinoma, gleason 3+3=6, Focal minimal equivocal involvement of margin(block , pt2c pnx mx, see cancer checklist and comment. Comment: The area of questionable margin involvement in block 8 consists of ink at a somewhat distorted glandular structure immediately adjacent to an area exhibiting unequivocal perineural invasion. The area in question is at the apex of an instrumentation defect into the prostate tissue with discontinuous prostate tissue external to this area of equivocal involvement. In my judgement this most likely represents focal minimal margin involvement. It is possible, however, that others may disagree with this assessment. CAP APPROVED CANCER CASE SUMMARY CHECKLIST Procedure: Radical robotic prostectomy on 63 y/o patient Prostate Size: 56 grams Size: 4.5 x 4.5 cm Lymphnode sampling: No lymphnodes present Histologic type: Adenocarcinoma Histologic grade: Primary pattern Gleason 3 Secondary pattern gleason 3 Total gleason score: Gleason 6 Tumor quantitation: approximately 10% of prostate involved by tumor. Some extending to other lobe Extraprostatic extension: Not identified Seminal Vesicle invasion: not identified Margins: Equivocal minimal involvement(block Lymph-vascular invasion: present(perineural) Pathologic staging: pT2c pNX pMX A fairly decent report except for the margin mentioned. Could this mean some cancer remains/was missed? It worries me with the positive margin it may come back. I have already lost my mom to stage 4 base of tonfue squamous cell carcinoma 5 years ago. Losing dad would be devasting. I will explain his life threatening complication(dvt and bilateral pulmonary embolism as a result of the surgery) later, but my hands are cramping and my eyes are strained from typing on and focusing on this tablet screen.
Posts.Title: Hello everyone. My dad had/has prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hi, take a deep breath, you are getting a bit ahead of yourself. A 2.8 increase in one year on your PSA is certainly warranting of investigation and work up by a urologist, but by no means is it an indicator of "Fatal prostate cancer". There are other things that can cause a spike in PSA like that, prostate enlargement(BPH), and inflammation(prostatitis) of the gland can do that, especially inflammation. And of course, prostate cancer should always be considered a possibility, but there should not be any conclusions drawn. Good rule of thumb that I have seen doctors use is that "You don't have cancer until you are formally diagnosed". While there may be some fallicies with that line of thinking, it is a good thing to take into consideration with prostate cancer, and it can help curb unneccessary worrying and anxiety. IF, and that is a BIG if-- your doctor suspects the possibility of prostate cancer, he or she may recommend a repeat biopsy just for confirmation, and if that too reads elevated, then he or she will likely decide to do further work up, such as a DRE and a biopsy. If they decide on doing a DRE, keep in mind that it needs to be done AFTER any PSA test, as that can cause a false high reading, a DRE stimulates the prostate, and causes it to secrete more PSA into the blood stream. And then if based on the PSA and DRE, your doctor can determine your need for a biopsy, most of which are the standard 12 core biopsies, where they take 12 samples from various areas of the prostate, then they send those samples to pathology for determination of if there is malignancy present or not. A biopsy is the way to go in determining whether or not someone has prostate cancer, as it gives you a more direct look at the behavior of the cells in the gland-- a PSA test cant differentiate between cancer, and prostate enlargement or prostatitis. The biopsy is generally pretty safe with no complications, though some people have had a rough time with it. One of the complications that comes from a prostate biopsy is an infection, but this is relatively uncommon now, as the ordering physician will give you some anti biotics to take before and after the biopsy in order to cut down the risk of an infection following the procedure. With a standard prostate biopsy, you will be given a local anasthetic, you wont be put to sleep unless you request to, and they will likely prescribe you one or two anti anxiety pills to take prior in order to help you relax. It doesn't hurt, you might feel a bit of pressure and you might feel a tug when the doctor pulls the samples out, but it really is not a painful procedure. After that is done, go home and relax, and when you are ready, go back to doing your usual activities and await the appointment to discuss the results of the biopsy, which should be about a week afterward, 10 days at most. And at that time, you can decide what to do if anything needs to be done, based off the results.
Posts.Signature: Dad Dx PCa 03/19/13 01/25/13 Blood test revealed PSA of 4.2 referred to urologist 02/08/13 Second PSA then DRE, normal feel to gland 03/08/13 Results of biopsy: 5/12 cores positive for PCa +PNI Gleason 3+3=6 cT1NxMx surgery scheduled 04/23/13 RRP: no obvious disease outside of gland 04/30/13 Path report: Tumor involved both lobes just barely into opposite side Gleason score same as biopsy +PNI Stage upgraded to pT2c 05/06/13 Unable to remove catheter due to leaking, attempt again two weeks later 05/08/13 Dad collapsed going to car, workup @ local hospital revealed DVT and extensive bilateral pulmonary emboli. transferred to larger facility 05/09/13 Dad admitted to SICU 05/11/13 Dad admitted to regular room 05/12/13 Discharged from Hospital 05/20/13 Catheter finally removed 06/18/13 First post-op PSA: <<0.04 All PSA tests until Jan 31 2017 were <<0.04 01/31/17 Last PSA test 0.13 Retest in 4 months + imaging studies

Posts.Title: PSA INCREASE 2.8 in one year. Doc not alarmed.

Posts.Content: Thanks again and im guessing with the stage being t2 nx mx, the doctor felt no need to assess for lymphnode and distant metastasis based on his psa and gleason score. He is now almost 7 months out from the bilateral pulmonary embolism that caused him to collapse in the yard. When I got to him, I thought he was gone because his eyes were rolled to the back of his head. It was determined the clots developed from the surgery and he was put on xarelto to dissolve as much of them as possible. He is now off of that and hopefully wint have another vte event. He still hasnt gotten his strength back, but at least he is still here. He does unfortunately have a hernia at one of the incision sites that he is going to address this month. Gotta be sure to tell that doc about his clots from the PCa surgery.

Posts.Title: Hello everyone. My dad had/has prostate cancer

Posts.Content: In regards to the focal MINIMAL equivical margin involvement, after research on the term "equivocal" it basically means uncertain. So in essence I guess it could be said focal minimal uncertain margin involvement. Im taking that as at least isnt blatantly obvious involvement. Plus his two PSA tests so far indicate the surgery did remove all the cancer that was precent. Plus minimal is also a good word here.

Posts.Title: Hello everyone. My dad had/has prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello all. I went in for bloodwork on myself yesterday. And though I'm uninsured, my office has a program going where if you are in good standing with them-- no overdue payments, unpaid copays, etc, you can get your lab work done with a wide range of assays-- BMP, renal function, liver function, glucose, electrolyte, CBC, etc, and get all that done for $16 bucks!!! Before, it was ~$270 for a similar set of assays. Anyway on to the relevant point. Given that my dad had prostate cancer, my physician went ahead and included PSA as part of the assays to be done, not only to screen as per family history, but to establish a baseline down the road. I got my results today, and he said my PSA was 0.53 ng/mL, which he said is excellent. His lab uses 2.5 as the cutoff threshold for what would constitute an elevated PSA, so mine fell very well within normal parameters. Given my dad's history, I will be getting PSA screens every 5 years when I go in for general blood work then(I will of course get all my regular assays done once a year as I've been doing for a while now. Now, I know it may seem silly for a 31 year old to get a PSA test done, but considering I was already there, and that there is nothing else special required to do it, and it being super cheap through their good standing program, I figure why not? It was of no inconvenience to me, and it sets a baseline for the future. Of course I know with age at some point, the gland will begin to enlarge, and that itself will increase PSA to a limited degree, but given my dad's history, I think getting an early start on watching for it is a good idea. I feel like this way I can stay a step ahead of the curve. FWIW: All other assays, including glucose and total cholesterol were very good. HDL could use a bit of an increase, but dr was happy since it was actually up from the prior assay. I feel like by noting what went on with my dad's bout with PC, and reading the stuff from here and other reputable sources, I will be more than prepared should the day(heaven forbid) come that I get diagnosed with prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Dad is doing good. He too got good results on his latest blood work. Does have polyneuropathy in his feet now-- Dr said quite likely from years and years of standing on a concrete floor at work-- he's an ironworker.Been pulling 64 hour weeks up till the past two weeks or so. Just got his DOT physical to keep his CDL, and he passed it with flying colors too. Looking at him now, you would never have known he had cancer or suffered pulmonary embolism from surgery.

Posts.Title: So PCP tested MY PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by hollienbilly My name is Hollie and my husband (45) was diagnosed with prostate cancer on 1/14/14. He has no signs or symptoms of the cancer. They started him on hormone therapy and after 6 weeks his psa fell to 139 and then after another 6 weeks it is down to 39. I am very glad to see the numbers drop but does this mean they will go back up faster as well and the cells become resistant? I have so many questions just not sure where to start?? Hello Hollie, I must say that is an astronomically high PSA level, I dont want to be a downer or negative perspn, but that almost certainly signifies advanced proatate cancer. But he has at least had a drastic response based on the hufe drop in his PSA. Unfortunately, these kind of cancers do become resistant to hormone therapy over time, but don't give up. Even after the pca becomes hormone resistant, there is still the option of immunotherapy. Perhaps now the moat well known form of immunotherapy for advanced prostate cancer is Provenge. It will not cure the cancer, but it can slow the progression of it and perhaps extend patients' lifespans. What they do with Provenge is they take immune cells from a patient's body, they then send them off to a lab, where they make the Provenge formula. Basically this "Programs" the patient's immune system to attack the cancer cells more effectively, and slow tje growth of the cancer. Again this will not cure the cancer, but it can perhaps slow it down, provide symptom reloef, and prolong life.

Posts.Title: Psa 5,928

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by crablad My husband was diagnosed at the age of 54 PSA 44, he is now 72 and his PSA is 30. We have had it go up and down, up and down. He has had probably every type of meds available plus three clinical trials. When his PSA went to 187 he started chemo with taxotere which worked great, some side effects. He is now on Xtandi...we will see how that goes. He is still strong and works hard...so there are lots of options...just find a good oncologist. Excellent example of why not to give up hope, despite the grim discoveries.

Posts.Title: Psa 5,928

Posts.Content: MO is a Medical Oncologist, and RO is a Radiation Oncologist. They often work together in advanced cases. A good MO and/or a good RO can get you many years of progression free survival. You say your metastases are in one location, well that is a good thing. Much easier to ttest them like that, than it is to treat widespread metastatic disease. One might could call your case "oligometstatic", which basically means the mets are limited in number and/or localized in one spot. Oligomwtastatic prostate cancer is quite often managed successfully with excellent results. I wont sugar coat it, it probably cannot be cured, but it can be CONTROLLED for MANY years before becoming bad enough, if ever, to the point it begins to limit survival. There are many men like you who have auccessful conyrolled their metastatic prostste cancer for 10+ years with the advances on treatment over the last couple decades. And not all those who died didn't pass becayse of their metastatic prostate cancer, rather some other illness, such as heart attack, or diabetic complications, Stroke, etc. Metastatic prostate cancer is indeed a scary beast with nasty teeth, but beasts can be caged and controlled.

Posts.Title: Roller Coaster Getting Bumpy last few weeks

Posts.Content: Hi there, hate to hear that you have metastatic disease. You are being sent to an oncologist because they are better at dealing with advanced cases, such as yours. Most urologists are surgeons, and nkt certified in oncology. An oncologist can administer medicine such as chemotherapy for metastatic disease, where as the typical urologist cannot. So its not surprising that youve been referred to oncology, in fact, its a prudent move to try and control the disease as long as possible.

Posts.Title: 300+PSA, still have hope?

Posts.Content: Thanks all my dad is now 65, was 63 at the time of the operation. Surgeon did give him the option of having a pelvic sling implanted, but dad decided it wasn't worth risking another episode of blood clots and another potential surgical hernia. He's come to to conclusion that he can accept the incontinence if it means the cancer is gone. He has had some regrets about choosing surgery over brachytherapy, but that's a moot point now, and plus with perineural invasion present, I think it was still a wise idea to have it removed. Seems that perineural invasion can turn an otherwise low risk cancer, such as Gleason 6, into a higher risk because of the proximimitg of those nerves to the capsule of the prostate. It's said that cancer cells can use those perineural spaces as a pathway to escape the gland.
Posts.Title: 2+ years since dad's prostate surgery

Posts.Content: Hi there, I hate to see such a high level of psa. Even in an extremely enlarged gland likely would not secrete that much PSA into the blood stream, but strange things happen. A general of thumb I've hears Dr's say is that "you don't have cancer until or unless you are confirmed as suche. But that DEFINITELY needs to be looked at, it is highly suspicious for PCa, and a biopsy needs to be done. And I would say imaging tests such as a bone scan, MRI, etc need to be done just on the safe side. My suspicion with such a high psa is that there may very well be cancer lying in there, and it's likely to be of a more aggressive type, such as 4+3=7 or gleason 8. But even then, that NY NO means would make eradication impossible. We need more information to get an idea of where he stands, and we can take it together. Remember, if it, and I mean IF, it does turn out to be cancer, know that you are not alone, and we will be more than happy to provide suport and advice. We are all in this thing together.

Posts.Title: Prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, long time no see, haven't been here in a while; but first let me get to the topic. April 23rd marked the 2 year anniversary of my dad's prostate surgery. He had his last PSA test in May, and once again, it read undetectable so looks like the focal minimally involved margin was of no significance. Still free of PCa. Unfortunately, he is permanently I continent to a degree now. His continence level is about 75% percent and he goes through two diapers a day. But al things considered, that's a small price that's well worth to. Pay to be rid of the cancer. I'm sorry I've not been here in a long time, I've not felt well for several months. Been having issues with my heart rate sky rocketing upon standing leaving me feeling dizzy and tired at times, so I haven't had the energy to do much. It's not as bad as it was but it's still there. At the worst it was shooting from 55 bp resting to over 110 to 120 the instant I stood up. Anyway just wanted to let y'all know how dad is doing and wish everyone the best and hope all of y'all continue to see good results as well. And for those new here, sorry to see you're a member of this "club", but this is a great place for advice and insight, plus you know you Are not alone. Hope everyone had a great Christmas and new year, and I plan to be on more now. Here's to more "Zeroes" and "undetectables". The post treatment PSA test I think is about the only test one wants to make a zero on!!

Posts.Title: 300+PSA, still have hope?

Posts.Content: At 71, he is on the borderline in terms of surgery vs radiation. If he doesn't have significant comorbidities such as heart disease, or pulmonry disease such as COPD, surgery should be ok for him. It indeed would be wise to consult with a radiation oncologist prior to the operation as well, given that it is Gleason 8 prostate cancer. As far as the bone scan goes, if it is positive, then the cancer is most likely not curable, but can still be treated quite well for symptom control, and extension of life and ptogression free survival. Here is something important to note. If surgery is chosen first, you still have another "sword" with radiation as adjuvant(planned secondary treatment to make the surgery more likeoy to be successful), or as salvage treatment that can still offer cure if surgery fails to rid the cancer in its entirety, provided the "missed cells" are still within the region of the prostate(prostate bed where the organ once layed before its removal. If radiation is chosen first, surgery is not likely(but not 100% out of the question) a second option, because radiation creates scar tissue, and that is very difficult for surgeons to operate through. Even though it is high grade cancer, he has several factors in his favor: no evidence of lymphnode invasion, no extraprostatic extension detected, no perineural invasion noted, only 2 cores positive, and total involvement 10% or less(your dad's being 8% as your signature tells us).Based on these vital statistics, I would say your fathervhas a pretty good chance of cure. With it being a high grade cancer, PSA tests post treatment are likely to be more frequent than that of a person with Gleason 6 cancer, because gleason 8 has a higher chance e of returning, though certainly not guaranteed to do so by any means. Your dad has a lot in his favor, so id say his prognosis is good.

Posts.Title: PSA Test Result analysis (6 weeks post-surgery)?

Posts.Content: Man, I hate to hear that but know thst a 20-30% chance of cure is still a chance, and much better than zero. And with what oncologists have avilable today to battle prostate cancer, men with recurrent or advanced disease can still live many years, and progression free as well. And yeah, it would be helpful to talk with a radiation oncologist. They can't do treatment unless you give them the ok to do so. So while they may suggest it, ultimately you are the ones with the keys and if you don't wish to proceed, they can't make you. Perhaps have a discussion with a separate medical oncologist as well, and see what they say. Second opinions can never hurt.

But that DEFINITELY needs to be looked at, it is highly suspicious for PCa, and a biopsy needs to be done. And I would say imaging tests such as a bone scan, MRI, etc need to be done just on the safe side. My suspicion with such a high psa is that there may very well be cancer lying in there, and it's likely to be of a more aggressive type, such as 4+3=7 or gleason 8. But even then, that NY NO means would make eradication impossible. We need more information to get an idea of where he stands, and we can take it together. Remember, if it, and I mean IF, it does turn out to be cancer, know that you are not alone, and we will be more than happy to provide suport and advice. We are all in this thing together.

Posts.Title: Prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: At 71, he is on the borderline in terms of surgery vs radiation. If he doesn't have significant comorbidities such as heart disease, or pulmonry disease such as COPD, surgery should be ok for him. It indeed would be wise to consult with a radiation oncologist prior to the operation as well, given that it is Gleason 8 prostate cancer. As far as the bone scan goes, if it is positive, then the cancer is most likely not curable, but can still be treated quite well for symptom control, and extension of life and ptogression free survival. Here is something important to note. If surgery is chosen first, you still have another "sword" with radiation as adjuvant(planned secondary treatment to make the surgery more likeoy to be successful), or as salvage treatment that can still offer cure if surgery fails to rid the cancer in its entirety, provided the "missed cells" are still within the region of the prostate(prostate bed where the organ once layed before its removal. If radiation is chosen first, surgery is not likely(but not 100% out of the question) a second option, because radiation creates scar tissue, and that is very difficult for surgeons to operate through. Even though it is high grade cancer, he has several factors in his favor: no evidence of lymphnode invasion, no extraprostatic extension detected, no perineural invasion noted, only 2 cores positive, and total involvement 10% or less(your dad's being 8% as your signature tells us).Based on these vital statistics, I would say your fathervhas a pretty good chance of cure. With it being a high grade cancer, PSA tests post treatment are likely to be more frequent than that of a person with Gleason 6 cancer, because gleason 8 has a higher chance e of returning, though certainly not guaranteed to do so by any means. Your dad has a lot in his favor, so id say his prognosis is good.

Posts.Title: Dad had first appointment with surgeon

Posts.Content: Walking will also help to prevent blood clots. My dad developed blood clots after his surgery in April, which I attribute to immobility in bed because of his catheter, and the nurses forgot to turn on the air pump in his compression device as he stayed overnight, this I believe predisposed him to a higher risk, and the immobility was the trigger. Get to walking whenever you can to help encourage blood flow and resuce the risk of blood pooling in your legs. If you don't feel like walking, you can flex your feet up and down for a few minutes several times a day, and/or you can take your feet, raise them a bit and use your ankle to make circular motions with your feet, this can also encourage good blood flow. You can also lay back in a recliner amd this will elevate your feet slightly above hip level, this I've heard can also aid in reducing blood clot risk.
